Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 6342-6348Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (175) Google Scholar). mP-selectin was first perfused over the PSGL-1 surface, because mP-selectin is primarily dimeric in nonionic detergents and should therefore bind to PSGL-1 with higher avidity than monomeric forms of P-selectin. Injection of mP-selectin resulted in a biphasic binding response, followed by a relatively slow rate of dissociation (Fig. 3 A). Preincubation of mP-selectin with the blocking anti-P-selectin mAb G1 abrogated binding to PSGL-1. In contrast, preincubation with the nonblocking anti-P-selectin mAb S12 augmented the response, due to the larger mass of the mP-selectin-S12 complex. Prebinding of PL1 to the PSGL-1 surface blocked binding of mP-selectin, whereas prebinding of PL2 did not block binding (Fig. 3 B). Injection of EDTA rapidly reversed the binding of mP-selectin, consistent with the known Ca2+dependence of selectin binding to PSGL-1 (data not shown). These data demonstrate that mP-selectin binds specifically to immobilized PSGL-1. Because mP-selectin is dimeric and oligomeric, it could not be reliably used to measure the affinity and kinetics of binding. Injection of sP-selectin resulted in a rapid binding response, followed by rapid dissociation (Fig. 4 A). Preincubation of sP-selectin with mAb G1 blocked binding. In contrast, preincubation with mAb S12 increased the binding response, due to the larger mass of the sP-selectin-S12 complex and to an increase in binding avidity presumably caused by cross-linking of some sP-selectin molecules by the bivalent S12 IgG. Prebinding of PL1 to the PSGL-1 surface blocked binding of sP-selectin (Fig. 4 B). After prebinding of PL2, however, injection of increasing concentrations of sP-selectin caused progressive increases in the binding response. sP-selectin did not bind to immobilized PSGL-1 in the presence of EDTA (data not shown). These data demonstrate that sP-selectin also binds specifically to immobilized PSGL-1. Because it is monomeric, sP-selectin dissociates much more rapidly from PSGL-1 than does mP-selectin. Because the BIAcore detects binding as a change in refractive index, the rapid kinetics of binding of sP-selectin to immobilized PSGL-1 may be difficult to distinguish from bulk refractive changes, especially when high protein concentrations are injected. We therefore wished to conduct parallel injections of P-selectin on both a PSGL-1 surface and a control, nonbinding surface. In this manner, RU attributed to bulk refractive index on the control surface could be subtracted from the total RU measured on the PSGL-1 surface, yielding specific binding. Treatment of PSGL-1 with sialidase abrogates binding to P-selectin, consistent with the requirement for sLex or related glycans as part of the binding site (26Moore K.L. Stults N.L. Diaz S. Smith D.L. Cummings R.D. Varki A. McEver R.P. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 118: 445-456Crossref PubMed Scopus (419) Google Scholar, 27Norgard K.E. Moore K.L. Diaz S. Stults N.L. Ushiyama S. McEver R.P. Cummings R.D. Varki A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12764-12774Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We immobilized PSGL-1 on two flow cells at comparable densities and perfused sialidase over one of the flow cells to remove sialic acid moieties from PSGL-1. Sialidase treatment eliminated binding of CSLEX-1, a mAb to sLex, but increased binding of LeuM1, a mAb to the nonsialylated Lexstructure (Fig. 5, A and B). Sialidase treatment did not appreciably affect binding of PL1, which recognizes a protein epitope near the N terminus of PSGL-1 (Fig. 5 C). Thus, the sialidase perfusion effectively removed sialic acid from PSGL-1, but did not remove PSGL-1 itself from the sensor surface. mP-selectin bound to nontreated PSGL-1 but not to sialidase-treated PSGL-1 (Fig. 5 D). These data further document the specificity of binding of P-selectin to immobilized PSGL-1, by showing that binding requires sialylation of PSGL-1. They also demonstrate that sialidase-treated PSGL-1 is an ideal control surface for distinguishing bulk refractive index changes from specific binding of P-selectin to PSGL-1. We measured the affinity of sP-selectin and Lec-EGF for PSGL-1 by injecting increasing concentrations of each protein over both nonsialidase-treated PSGL-1 and sialidase-treated PSGL-1. Although sP-selectin and Lec-EGF are monomeric by several criteria, there remained the possibility that small quantities of oligomers might develop prior to the assay. Because of mass action, low concentrations of oligomers would bind slowly relative to the major monomeric species. We therefore used a high flow rate (40 μl/min) and a short injection time (15 s) to favor monomer binding. This short infusion provided sufficient data points, since equilibrium binding was reached within 2–3 s. Injection of increasing concentrations of sP-selectin or Lec-EGF resulted in a rapid increase in refractive index on both PSGL-1 surfaces, followed by a rapid decrease to base line after the injection was completed (Fig. 6). The RU measured on the nonsialidase-treated surface were always higher than on the sialidase-treated surface. Injection of equivalent concentrations of human serum albumin on either surface yielded RU values identical to those observed for sP-selectin or Lec-EGF on the sialidase-treated surface (Fig. 6). Thus, the RU values on the sialidase-treated surface clearly reflected bulk refractive index changes rather than true binding to the surface. Subtraction of the value on the sialidase-treated surface from the value on the nonsialidase-treated surface yielded the specific binding of sP-selectin or Lec-EGF to PSGL-1. The equilibrium affinity of binding to PSGL-1 was measured in two ways (Fig. 7). In the first, the BIAevaluation software was used to plot the subtracted equilibrium response (R eq) versus the concentration of sP-selectin or Lec-EGF. Nonlinear curve fitting was used to derive the dissociation constant (K d). In the second, standard Scatchard analysis was used. Both methods yielded similar results and indicated that sP-selectin and Lec-EGF bound to a single class of sites on PSGL-1. The K d for sP-selectin was 320 ± 20 nm, as determined in multiple experiments using different preparations of sP-selectin (Table I). The K d for Lec-EGF was similar (Table I), although the results were slightly more variable because the smaller mass of Lec-EGF decreased the ratio of specific to nonspecific binding at higher input concentrations.Table ISummary of affinity and kinetic data for sP-selectin and Lec-EGF binding to PSGL-1P-selectin constructK d (nm) (nonlinear curve-fitting)k offk ons−1m−1s−1sP-selectin1-aMean ± S.D. of four determinations for equilibrium affinity measurements and of six determinations for dissociation rate constant measurements, using three different preparations of sP-selectin.320 ± 201.4 ± 0.14.4 × 106Lec-EGF1-bMean ± S.D. of seven determinations for equilibrium affinity measurements and of six determinations for dissociation rate constant measurements, using four different preparations of Lec-EGF.422 ± 891.6 ± 0.43.8 × 1061-a Mean ± S.D. of four determinations for equilibrium affinity measurements and of six determinations for dissociati

Expression of pipe in the somatic tissue of the Drosophila ovary is required for the formation of embryonic dorsal–ventral polarity. pipe, which encodes an enzyme similar to the glycosaminoglycan-modifying enzyme heparan sulfate 2-O-sulfotransferase, is expressed in a spatially restricted domain of follicle cells on the ventral side of the egg chamber. Mutations that affect follicular polarity correspondingly alter the spatial pattern of pipe expression. Directed expression of pipe in otherwise pipe mutant females restores embryonic lateral and ventral pattern elements and can orient the dorsal–ventral axis of the embryo. Thus, the localized expression of pipe and the spatially restricted modification of carbohydrate chains play pivotal roles in the mechanisms that establish embryonic pattern and integrate follicular and embryonic polarity.

We have identified and characterized Diva, which is a novel regulator of apoptosis. Sequence analysis revealed that Diva is a member of the Bcl-2 family of proteins containing Bcl-2 homology domain 1, 2, 3, and 4 (BH1, BH2, BH3, and BH4) regions and a carboxyl-terminal hydrophobic domain. The expression of Diva mRNA was detected in multiple embryonic tissues but was restricted to the ovary and testis in adult mice. The expression of Diva promoted the death of 293T, Ramsey, and T47D cells as well as that of primary sensory neurons, indicating that Diva is a proapoptotic protein. Significantly, Diva lacks critical residues in the conserved BH3 region that mediate the interaction between BH3-containing proapoptotic Bcl-2 homologues and their prosurvival binding partners. Consistent with this, Diva did not bind to cellular Bcl-2 family members including Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, Bcl-w, Mcl-1, and A1/Bfl-1. Furthermore, mutants of Diva lacking the BH3 region fully retained their proapoptotic activity, confirming that Diva promotes apoptosis in a BH3-independent manner. Significantly, Diva interacted with a viral Bcl-2 homologue (vBcl-2) encoded by the Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus. Consistent with these associations, apoptosis induced by Diva was inhibited by vBcl-2 but not by Bcl-XL. Importantly, Diva interacted with Apaf-1, an adapter molecule that activates caspase-9, a central death protease of the apoptotic pathway. The expression of Diva inhibited the binding of Bcl-XL to Apaf-1, as determined by immunoprecipitation assays. Thus, Diva represents a novel type of proapoptotic Bcl-2 homologue that promotes apoptosis independently of the BH3 region through direct binding to Apaf-1, thus preventing Bcl-XL from binding to the caspase-9 regulator Apaf-1. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 461-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar).Here we report the identification and characterization of Diva, a novel member of the Bcl-2 family that exhibits proapoptotic function. Unlike all known Bcl-2-related proapoptotic proteins, Diva lacks critical residues in the BH3 domain that are involved in the interaction between BH3-containing proapoptotic proteins and their binding partners. Furthermore, apoptosis induced by Diva does not require the conserved BH3 domain. Apoptosis induced by Diva was inhibited by the viral caspase inhibitor p35 and the dominant negative mutant of caspase-9, but not by Bcl-XL. Consistent with this, Diva can directly interact with Apaf-1 and displace Bcl-XL from the Apaf-1/Bcl-XL complex, suggesting that Diva inhibits Bcl-XL function through competitive binding to Apaf-1. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 461-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar). Here we report the identification and characterization of Diva, a novel member of the Bcl-2 family that exhibits proapoptotic function. Unlike all known Bcl-2-related proapoptotic proteins, Diva lacks critical residues in the BH3 domain that are involved in the interaction between BH3-containing proapoptotic proteins and their binding partners. Furthermore, apoptosis induced by Diva does not require the conserved BH3 domain. Apoptosis induced by Diva was inhibited by the viral caspase inhibitor p35 and the dominant negative mutant of caspase-9, but not by Bcl-XL. Consistent with this, Diva can directly interact with Apaf-1 and displace Bcl-XL from the Apaf-1/Bcl-XL complex, suggesting that Diva inhibits Bcl-XL function through competitive binding to Apaf-1. Marie Harwick for the generous supply of plasmids; and Mary A. Benedict and Luis del Peso for critical review of the manuscript.

The dimensions of the aqueous pore in aquaporins (AQP) 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 expressed in Xenopus laevisoocytes were probed by comparing the ability of various solutes to generate osmotic flow. By improved techniques, volume flows were determined from initial rates of changes. Identical values for the osmotic water permeability (L p) were obtained in swelling as in shrinkage experiments demonstrating, for the first time, that aquaporins are bidirectional. The reflection coefficients (ς) of urea, glycerol, acetamide, and formamide at 23 °C were: AQP0: 1, 1, 0.8, 0.6; AQP1: 1, 0.8, 1, 1; AQP2: 1, 0.8, 1, 1; AQP3: 1, 0.2, 0.7, 0.4; AQP4: 1, 0.9, 1, 1; and AQP5: 1, 1, 1, 0.8. As seen there is no clear connection between solute size and permeation. At 13 °C the ςs for AQP3 were 1, 0.4, 1, and 0.5; functionally, this pore narrows at lower temperatures. HgCl2 reversibly reduced theL p of AQP3 and increased ςglyc to 1 and ςform to 0.6. We conclude that the pore of the various aquaporins are structurally different and that a simple steric model is insufficient to explain solute-pore interactions. Aquaporins (AQPs)1 are a class of membrane proteins in which water transport is thought to take place via an aqueous pore by osmosis (1Van Os C.H. Deen P.M.T. Dempster J.A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1197: 291-309Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 2Verkman A.S. Van Hoek A.N. Ma T. Frigeri A. Skach W.R. Mitra A. Tamarappoo B.K. Farinas J. Am. J. Physiol. 1996; 270: C12-C30Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 3Agre P. Bonhivers M. Borgnia M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 14659-14662Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (394) Google Scholar). The physical dimensions, the location, and the chemical composition of the putative pore are largely unknown. Such parameters, however, will be central to the interpretation of structural data (4Walz T. Hirai T. Murata K. Heyman J.B. Mitsuoka K. Fujiyoshi Y. Smith B.L. Agre P. Engel A. Nature. 1997; 387: 624-626Crossref PubMed Scopus (385) Google Scholar, 5Cheng A. van Hoek A.N. Yager M. Verkman A.S. Mitra A.K. Nature. 1997; 387: 627-630Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar, 6Li H. Jap B.K. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1997; 4: 263-265Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar) and to the elucidation of the osmotic mechanism. Here we probe the pore size by testing the osmotic efficiencies of solutes of different molecular weights, dimensions, and chemical compositions; if the test solute can permeate the pore, the resulting water fluxes will be smaller than that caused by an impermeable solute (7Finkelstein A. Water Movement Through Lipid Bilayers, Pores, and Plasma Membranes, Theory and Reality. Wiley-Interscience, New York1987: 228Google Scholar, 8Hill A.E. J. Membr. Biol. 1994; 137: 197-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). To obtain precise measurements, it was necessary first to evaluate critically and to improve the Xenopus oocyte system as an assay of osmotic water transport. So far, water transport by aquaporins expressed in Xenopus oocytes have been investigated by challenging with hyposmolar solutions creating gradients of about 100 mosm for up to 30 min. This results in rates of swelling that vary with time. Furthermore, oocytes do not shrink as well as they swell when exposed to large hypertonic gradients (9Zhang R. Verkman A.S. Am. J. Physiol. 1991; 260: C26-C34Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We have improved the volume recording and the solution changing system to employ osmotic gradients as small as 2.5 mosm and as short as 5 s. In this way the transport parameters could be determined unambiguously from the initial rate of oocyte volume changes in both swelling and shrinkage experiments. We tested six aquaporins: AQP0 (10Zampighi G.A. Hall J.E. Ehring G.R. Simon S.A. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 2255-2275Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar, 11Mulders S.M. Preston G.M. Deen P.M.T. Guggino W.B. van Os C.H. Agre P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9010-9016Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar), a major intrinsic protein of the lens fibers; AQP1 (12Preston G.M. Agre P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 11110-11114Crossref PubMed Scopus (725) Google Scholar), present predominantly in red blood cells and kidney proximal tubules cells; AQP2 (13Fushimi K. Uchida S. Hara Y. Hirata Y. Marumo F. Sasaki S. Nature. 1993; 361: 549Crossref PubMed Scopus (874) Google Scholar), present in the kidney collecting duct; AQP3 (14Echevarrı́a M. Windhager E.E. Tate S.S. Frindt G. Proc. Natl. The data demonstrate that the water flow through aquaporins are bidirectional and that there are structural differences among the various subtypes. Furthermore, for a given aquaporin, there was no relation between the size of the test solutes and their permeability. Human AQP1 and rat AQP5 were obtained from American Type Culture Collection (ATCC 99538 and ATCC 87185). Human AQP2 was a gift from Dr. K. Fushimi. Rat AQP3 and -4 were a gift from Dr. S. Nielsen. Preparation of mRNA, injection into and maintenance of theXenopus oocytes were carried out as described previously (20Zeuthen T. Meinild A.-K. Klaerke D.A. Loo D.D.F. Wright E.M. Belhage B. Litman T. Biol. Cell. 1997; 89: 307-312PubMed Google Scholar, 21Meinild A.-K. Klaerke D.A. Loo D.D.F. Wright E.M. Zeuthen T. J. Physiol. 1998; 508.1: 15-22Crossref Scopus (163) Google Scholar). Briefly, cRNA was synthesized by the mCAP In Vitrotranscription kit from Stratagene, and the appropriate RNA polymerases (T7 or T3) were used for run off transcription of sense-cRNA. Oocytes were isolated and defolliculated with collagenase (Boehringer Mannheim). For expression, the oocytes were injected with 10–50 ng of cRNA and incubated at 19 °C in Kulori medium (in mm: 90 NaCl, 1 KCl, 1 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 5 HEPES, pH 7.4) for 3–7 days before experiments. Healthy oocytes with membrane potentials more negative than −20 mV were used. The experiments were performed as described in detail previously (20Zeuthen T. Meinild A.-K. Klaerke D.A. Loo D.D.F. Wright E.M. Belhage B. Litman T. Biol. Cell. 1997; 89: 307-312PubMed Google Scholar). Oocytes were placed in a chamber that was perfused continuously. The chamber had a total volume of 30 μl, and the control bathing solution could be changed to a test solution within 5 s (90% complete). The oocytes were impaled with two microelectrodes that served to determine the membrane potential, and, importantly, they stabilized the oocyte in the chamber. The presence of microelectrodes did not affect the measurements (22Loo D.D.F. Zeuthen T. Chandy G. Wright E.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 13367-13370Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar). This was confirmed in experiments where the oocytes were held from the outside by two microelectrodes, the tips of which had been melted into 100 μm spheres. Oocytes were observed from below via an inverted microscope connected to a charge-coupled camera. The oocyte volume change was visualized on line. Noise levels were about 0.03%, which is equal to a oocyte volume change of about 0.3 nl. The temperature of the experimental chamber was 23 °C but could be lowered by leading the bathing solutions through ice. The control bathing solution contained in mm: 90 NaCl, 20 mannitol, 2 KCl, 1 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 10 HEPES, pH 7.4, 214 mosm. Hyposmotic test solutions were obtained by removing mannitol and hyperosmotic solutions by adding mannitol. The mannitol contents were adjusted so that the removal of all mannitol from the test solution led to a reduction of the osmolarity of 20 mosm. To induce large rates of oocyte swelling, we used hypotonic solutions that contained 45 mm NaCl and 10 mm mannitol, otherwise as above. This gives an osmolarity of 120 mosm, 94 mosm lower than the control solution. Osmolarities were measured in duplicate for each experiment by freezing point depression (Roebling). The osmotic water permeabilityL p was obtained from JV=−ALpΔπ(Eq. 1) The volume flow, J V, was determined from the initial rate of change of oocyte volume. L p are given per true cm2 of oocyte membrane, A. The oocytes had an average diameter of 1.35 mm, which gives a volume of 1.35 μl and an apparent surface area of 5.9 mm2. Folding of the membrane increases this area by nine times to A= 0.53 cm2 (23Zampighi G.A. Kreman M. Boorer K.J. Loo D.D.F. Bezanilla F. Chandy G. Hall J.E. Wright E.M. J. Membr. Biol. 1995; 148: 65-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar). Δπ is the difference between the osmolarity of the test solution and the control bathing solution. The ability to permeate was assessed from reflection coefficients (ς): ςurea, ςglycerol, ςacetamide, and ςformamide were derived from the initial rate of shrinkage induced by test solutions made 20 mosm hyperosmolar by adding either urea (M r 60), glycerol (M r92), acetamide (M r 63) or formamide (M r 45) to the control solution JV=−ςALpΔπ(Eq. 2) This shrinkage was compared with the one induced by adding mannitol (M r 182) (Eq. 1) and ς obtained by division. If the test solute permeates, ς is smaller than 1. Alternatively, ςs could be derived from the initial rates of cell swelling induced by replacing the 20 mosm of mannitol in the control solution by 2 mosm of the test solute JV=(1−ς)ALpΔπ(Eq. 3) where Δπ equals 20 mosm. All numbers are given as mean ± S.E., n is the number of experiments in at least 4 oocytes unless otherwise indicated. When the external osmolarity was changed, the oocyte volume began to change within 1 s. For oocytes expressing aquaporins, the rate of change decreased progressively with time; when the bathing solution was returned to the control solution, the oocyte volume returned rapidly toward its control value (Fig. 1, A and B). There was a direct relationship between the difference in the initial and the final slope of the volume change during the osmotic challenge (Fig. 1 C, α) and the initial slope during the subsequent recovery (Fig. 1C, β): The two values were equal to a first approximation. For osmotic challenges in the range −20 to +20 mosm, β equaled 1.2 ± 0.06 times α (r = 0.98, n = 73). The magnitudes of the effect varied, the larger the expressed water permeability the larger α and β; changes were virtually absent (α and β = 0) in native oocytes (Fig. 1 D). Both α and β were smaller when measured at 13 °C compared with 23 °C. The Arrhenius activation energy E a was 10 ± 1 kcal mol−1(5 oocytes) for α and 11 ± 3 (5 oocytes) for β. TheseE as are about 50% larger than those obtained for the L p (see below). There was no change in membrane potential when the external osmolarity was changed by means of mannitol. Furthermore, inhibitors of volume regulatory responses had no effects on the volume responses: 100 μm DIDS (24Ackerman M.J. Wickman K.D. Clapham D.E. J. Gen. Physiol. 1994; 103: 153-179Crossref PubMed Scopus (211) Google Scholar), 1 mm furosemide, 100 μm bumetanide, or 100 μm cytocalasin B (data not shown). Hyperosmotic (shrinkage) experiments were performed by adding up to 20 mm of mannitol to the control bathing solution, whereas hyposmotic experiments (swelling) were obtained by removing up to 20 mm of mannitol. The L ps obtained were independent of the direction of the osmotic gradient. These experiments were compared with the effects of exposing the oocyte to hyposmolarities of −94 mosm for each oocyte. A typical set of recordings are shown in Fig. 2. The slope defines the osmotic water permeability L p when the initial rates of change are plotted as a function of the osmotic driving force. Nature. 1997; 387: 627-630Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar), 5.1 ± 0.2 (8Hill A.E. J. Membr. Biol. 1994; 137: 197-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar), 6.3 ± 0.8 (8Hill A.E. J. These values are similar to those above except for that of glycerol, which is significantly lower. The effects of HgCl2was tested as a function of time. At time zero 1 mm of HgCl2 was added to the control bathing solution, subsequently L p and ς were measured every 1 to 2 min by short lasting additions of 20 mosm of mannitol or test solute. In agreement with the observations of others, AQP1, 2, 3, and 5 were sensitive to HgCl2, whereas AQP0 and AQP4 were not. The rate, however, at which HgCl2 inhibited AQP1 was up to 10 times slower than that reported by others (34Echevarrı́a M. Windhager E.E. Frindt G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25079-25082Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar). After 10 min of exposure to 1 mm HgCl2, L pwas reduced by 38% ± 3 (7 oocytes). After 30 min of exposure, the inhibition was 61% ± 3 (5 oocytes) equivalent to anL p of 3.4 ± 0.4 (10−5 cm s−1 (osmol liter−1)−1). This is still about 8 times higher than that of the native oocyte membrane. If 5 mm HgCl2 was used instead of 1 mm, similar degrees of inhibitions were obtained, but the effects occurred three times faster (4 oocytes, data not shown). We have no explanation for this slow response, it cannot be because of methodology, because the inhibitions of AQP2, 3, and 5 were complete in a few minutes, which is as fast as those reported by others. In AQP3, HgCl2 affected both L p and the ςs. After 10 min of exposure to HgCl2, theL p was reduced by 76% ± 5 (4 oocytes). Within 15 min the inhibition was complete at 88% ± 4, equivalent to anL p of 0.9 ± 0.2 (10−5 cm s−1 (osmol liter−1)), which is close to the value of native oocytes treated with HgCl2. Initially ςglyc was small, about 0.25 (Table I), but after only 3–5 min in HgCl2 (i.e. before theL p was fully inhibited), additions of 20 mosm of glycerol to the bathing solutions produced the same oocyte shrinkage as did mannitol, ςglyc = 1 (6 oocytes tested). A similar effect was found for formamide; ςformincreased to 0.6 after 5 min of HgCl2 exposure (3 oocytes tested). The effects of HgCl2 on L p were fully reversible (even without the application of β-mercaptoethanol) within 10–20 min. Common to both native and aquaporin-expressing oocytes, 1 mm of HgCl2 caused the oocytes to swell and to stabilize at a volume 5% (range from 2 to 8) larger than the control volume; concurrently, the membrane potential fell typically from −35 mV to −5 mV. Native oocytes behaved as almost ideal osmometers (Fig. 1 D). In contrast, oocytes that expressed aquaporins exhibited volume changes that were markedly nonlinear; most striking is the rapid return to control volume after the osmotic challenge (Fig. 1, A and B). During the osmotic challenge, there appears to be a gradual build up of a counter osmotic force, which reduces the rate of volume change (Fig. 1 C, by the amount α). When the external solution is returned to control solution, this counter osmotic force remains and gives rise to the fast rate of return (Fig. 1 C, β) of the oocyte volume toward the control volume, hence α ≅ β. Most likely, this behavior results from a build up of an unstirred layer inside the oocyte and is governed by the very slow rates of interdiffusion between water and the intracellular proteinaceous solutes (25Dick, D. A. T. (1966) pp. 155, Butterworth, LondonGoogle Scholar). When the external solution is returned to control, most of the water in the unstirred layer will return to the bathing solution by osmosis across the oocyte membrane; the flux into the oocyte will be comparatively small, because it is determined by the slow process of interdiffusion (25Dick, D. A. T. (1966) pp. 155, Butterworth, LondonGoogle Scholar). Consequently, the oocyte volume returns to the control value. It is unlikely that an ion specific, membrane bound, volume regulatory mechanism should be operating to any great extent. The osmotic effects were not associated with changes in the membrane potential and were insensitive to inhibitors of volume regulation. Furthermore, the nonlinearity effects (α and β) had activation energies of about 10 kcal mol−1, whereas the volume regulatory cotransport mechanism has E as of more than 20 kcal mol−1 (26Ellory J.C. Hall A.C. Comp. Biochem. Physiol. 1988; 90A: 533-537Crossref Scopus (26) Google Scholar). From the analysis above, we conclude that only the initial rate of change of the oocyte volume gives a valid measure of theL p. Inspection of the curves in Fig. 1, Aand B, shows that an L p based on volume change observed after 120 s will be estimated a factor 2.5 too low and if based on changes observed after 30 s, a factor 1.7 too low. Thus part of the variability in the data reported in the literature could arise if investigators based their L p values on volume changes obtained at different times. The values of E a will also depend on the time at which the volume change is determined. Because of the highE a of the nonlinearity effects (Fig. 1 C, α), volume changes recorded at 13 °C will exhibit less change than volume changes obtained at 23 °C. Consequently, the apparentE a will be smaller the later the volume changes are recorded. The difference between the E as reported by us, about 7 kcal mol−1, and those in the literature of about 4 kcal mol−1, can easily be attributed to this effect. If we base our estimates on values obtained after 60 s, instead of initial values, we also obtain E as of about 4 kcal mol−1. By applying small and short lasting osmotic challenges we show, for the first time, that theL p derived from shrinkage experiments and swelling experiments are the same. Thus the aquaporins are bidirectional,i.e. they do not rectify water flows. The aquaporins exhibited ςs lower than 1 for a number of solutes, which demonstrates interactions between water and solute flow in the aqueous pathway. The possibility that the test solute should cross the membrane via another route and thereby alter the osmotic driving force across the pore can be excluded. First, we deal with initial rates of flows and determine the rate of water flow within 10 s. As can be calculated, such periods are too short for any significant osmolarity to build up inside the oocyte. Second, ς for all test solutes in the native oocyte was one, similar to that for mannitol, which is impermeable. Third, there was no general connection between the type of the solute and the pattern of ςs (Table I). In some AQPs the smallest solute formamide had a low ς whereas in others it had a ς of 1. If, say, formamide could permeate via the protein-lipid interphase of the expressed aquaporins, ςform would be small for all aquaporins. Finally, it can be excluded that the low ς should arise from some kind of blockage by the solute inside the pore. If the test solutes should cause a physical reduction of the cross-section of the channel, we would not obtain the same ς in shrinkage experiments as in swelling experiments (Fig. 3). Our data suggest that there are specific interactions between the pore and the test solutes and exclude an entirely steric model where the solute and pore are viewed as having well defined dimensions (7Finkelstein A. Water Movement Through Lipid Bilayers, Pores, and Plasma Membranes, Theory and Reality. Wiley-Interscience, New York1987: 228Google Scholar, 8Hill A.E. J. Membr. Biol. 1994; 137: 197-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Consider the van der Waals dimensions of the solutes employed (in Å): mannitol (7.4 × 8.2 × 12), urea (3.6 × 5.2 × 5.4), glycerol (4.8 × 5.1 × 7.8), acetamide (3.8 × 5.2 × 5.4), and formamide (3.4 × 4.4 × 5.4) (27Gutiérrez A.M. González E. Echevarrı́a M. Hernández C.S. Whittembury G. J. Membr. Biol. 1995; 143: 189-197Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). For AQP1, -2, and -4 only ςglyc was lower than 1 (Table I). Accordingly, glycerol permeates the pores, yet the glycerol molecule is not the smallest. In AQP3, ςform is smaller than ςglyc, which is smaller than ςacet. Yet, glycerol is larger than acetamide and they are both larger than urea which does not permeate. Thus pore size and van der Waal dimensions of the solutes are insufficient to explain the sequences of ςs observed. Part of the explanation could be solute-pore interactions. If, for example, the –NH2 and –OH of the solutes formed hydrogen bonds with oxygens facing the pore wall, the effective size of the solute would be smaller by 1.4 A (28Hille B. Ionic Channels of Excitable Membranes. Sinauer Associates Inc., Sunderland, Massachusetts1992: 607Google Scholar). The effects of lowering the temperature for AQP3 demonstrates that the pore dimensions are not fixed entities (Table I); ςacetincreased to 1 and ςglyc and ςform doubled. Possibly AQP3 undergoes conformational changes that narrow the pore diameter. This would also explain the low E aobtained for volume flows induced by glycerol gradients;E a would result from two processes, the osmotic flow of water and the exclusion of glycerol at reduced temperature. Interestingly, ςglyc increased to 1 and ςform doubled under the influence of HgCl2, which also suggests a conformatinal narrowing of the pore. Single channel permeabilities and reflection coefficients (Table I) can be combined to suggest dimensions of the rate-limiting (the narrow) part of the aqueous pore. Single channel permeabilities are (in cm3 s−1 10−14) for AQP0, 0.25 (29Yang B. Verkman A.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16140-16146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar), 0.015 (23Zampighi G.A. Kreman M. Boorer K.J. Loo D.D.F. Bezanilla F. Chandy G. Hall J.E. Wright E.M. J. Membr. Biol. 1995; 148: 65-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar); AQP1, 4.6 (30Zeidel M.L. Ambudkar S.V. Smith B.L. Agre P. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 7436-7440Crossref PubMed Scopus (521) Google Scholar), 1.4 (23Zampighi G.A. Kreman M. Boorer K.J. Loo D.D.F. Bezanilla F. Chandy G. Hall J.E. Wright E.M. J. Membr. Chem. 1997; 272: 16140-16146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar). Now the reflection coefficients for AQP1, AQP2, and AQP4 were similar. If this means that their cross-sections are equal, the narrow part of the pore of AQP1 and AQP2 should have the same length, whereas that for AQP4 should be 6 times shorter. It appears that AQP3 has the largest pore cross-section, but because its single channel permeability is similar to that of AQP1 and AQP2, the length of the narrow part of its pore should be longer. These estimates, based naively on macroscopic hydrodynamics, should be viewed with great caution. Furthermore, the variability in the reported single channel permeabilities calls for further studies. Our data clearly shows that AQP3 is permeable to water. Expression of the protein increased the water permeability of the oocyte about 20-fold; theL p was inhibited by HgCl2 and had a low activation energy. This agrees with some studies (15Ishibashi K. Sasaki S. Fushimi K. Uchida S. Kuwahara M. Saito H. Furukawa T. Nakajima K. Yamaguchi M. Gojobori T. Marumo F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 6273-6369Google Scholar, 34Echevarrı́a M. Windhager E.E. Frindt G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25079-25082Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar), but conflicts with others (16Ma T. Frigeri A. Hasegawa H. Verkman A.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 21845-21849Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We found AQP3 to be permeable to glycerol by a mechanism that had a low activation energy and was sensitive to HgCl2 in a reversible manner. This agrees with the findings reported in Ref. 15Ishibashi K. Sasaki S. Fushimi K. Uchida S. Kuwahara M. Saito H. Furukawa T. Nakajima K. Yamaguchi M. Gojobori T. Marumo F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 6273-6369Google Scholarbut conflicts with those of Ref. 34Echevarrı́a M. Windhager E.E. Frindt G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25079-25082Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar where it was reported that glycerol uptake was determined by a high activation energy and was unaffected by mercurials. Now, the latter study employed radioactive uptakes and long term swellings, methods that report on the rate of transport by all types of mechanisms, but may be too crude to detect whether a given ς is lower than 1. Our finding of a ς smaller than 1 only shows that the solute can enter and permeate through the aqueous pore, it does not show whether the resulting flux is large enough to be detected in tracer experiments, and it may not detect parallel pathways that depend on other kinds of transport mechanisms. The controversy could therefore arise if AQP3 had two parallel pathways for glycerol, an aqueous pathway and a mechanism that depended on conformational changes. AQP3 is able to sustain a transport of urea (15Ishibashi K. Sasaki S. Fushimi K. Uchida S. Kuwahara M. Saito H. Furukawa T. Nakajima K. Yamaguchi M. Gojobori T. Marumo F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. Our results show that this transport does not take place by diffusion in the aqueous pathway. AQP4 was found by us to be permeable to glycerol, characterized by a ς of 0.8. It has been concluded from radioactive uptakes, however, that glycerol was impermeable (18Jung J.S. Bhat R.V. Preston G.M. Guggino W.B. Baraban J.M. Agre P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 13052-13056Crossref PubMed Scopus (630) Google Scholar). As discussed above, such studies may be too crude to detect if ς is close to but significantly different from 1. Deen P.M.T. Rousselte G. Tacnet F. Riproche P. Pflügers Arch. 1996; 431: 408-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar) with ςs similar to those given in Table I. In AQP1, formamide (33Ma T. Frigeri A. Tsai S.-T. Verbavatz J.-M. Verkman A.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22756-22764Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and urea (33Ma T. Frigeri A. Tsai S.-T. Verbavatz J.-M. Guggino W.B. Agre P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1908-1912Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (361) Google Scholar) to be impermeable to glycerol. Our data for ςs are not directly compatible with those obtained in the intact animal cells. In red blood cells, ςs for several small hydrophilic molecules (among them urea, glycerol, acetamide, and formamide) have been reported to be smaller than one (35Toon M.R. Solomon A.K. J. Membr. In the basolateral cell membrane of rabbit proximal straight tubule, ςform was found to be 0.62 and ςacet was 0.95 (27Gutiérrez A.M. González E. Echevarrı́a M. Hernández C.S. Whittembury G. J. Membr. Biol. 1995; 143: 189-197Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). From the data in Table I and the anatomical location of the various aquaporins, these findings are difficult to reconcile with any one of the AQPs (AQP0–AQP5). It ought to be investigated whether other types of membrane proteins besides AQP1 contribute to the ς of the membranes of the red cell and the kidney proximal tubules. The urea transporter (39Olives B. Neau P. Bailly P. Hediger M.A. Rousselet G. Cartron J.P. Ripoche P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31649-31652Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 40Yang B. Verkman A.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 9369-9372Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar), the facilitated glucose transporter GLUT1 (41Loike J.D. Cao L. Kuang K. Vera J.C. Silverstein S.C. Fischbarg J. J. Gen. Physiol. 1993; 102: 897-906Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), and AQP3 (42Roudier N. Verbavatz J.-M. Maurel C. Ripoche P. Tacnet F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 8407-8412Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar) could be candidates in the red blood cell. It should be noted that values of ς less than 1 for small hydrophilic solutes are not inconceivable for proteins that besides other functions can sustain passive fluxes of water. In the human Na+/glucose/H2O cotransporter, the passive pathway for water had a ςform of 0.3 (21Meinild A.-K. Klaerke D.A. Loo D.D.F. Wright E.M. Zeuthen T. J. Physiol. 1998; 508.1: 15-22Crossref Scopus (163) Google Scholar). The transport properties of aquaporins must be derived from the initial rates of change of oocyte volume; because of the large rates of water fluxes involved, osmotic challenges lasting longer than 20 s are significantly influenced by intracellular unstirred layers. The pores of the aquaporins are bidirectional. There are structural differences among the various aquaporins. It appears that AQP3 has the widest cross-section, whereas AQP5 has the narrowest. In a complete description of structure and function, factors such as solute-pore interactions and thermally induced conformational changes of the pore dimensions should be included.

Laminin-1, a multifunctional glycoprotein of the basement membrane, consists of three different subunits, α1, β1, and γ1 chains. Previously, we used synthetic peptides to screen for biologically active sequences in the laminin α1 chain C-terminal globular domain (G domain) and identified several cell binding sequences (Nomizu, M., Kim, W. H., Yamamura, K., Utani, A., Song, S. Y., Otaka, A., Roller, P. P., Kleinman, H. K., and Yamada, Y. (1995) J. Biol. Chem. 270, 20583–20590). Here, we identify new cell binding sequences on the remainder of the laminin α1 chain by systematic peptide screening, using 208 overlapping synthetic peptides encompassing the central and N-terminal portions of the α1 chain. HT-1080 cell attachment activity to the peptides was evaluated using peptide-coated plastic substrates and peptide-conjugated Sepharose beads. Twenty five peptides showed cell attachment activities on either the peptide-coated plastic substrates and/or the peptide-conjugated Sepharose beads. A-13 (RQVFQVAYIIIKA) showed strongest cell attachment activity in both the assays. Cell attachment to 14 of the peptides was inhibited by heparin. EDTA and integrin antibodies inhibited cell adhesion to two of the peptides, A-13 and A-25, suggesting that these sites likely bind to integrins. These peptides inhibited cell attachment to laminin-1 but not to collagen I, suggesting these active sites are available on the intact molecule. Most of active sequences were localized on globular domains suggesting that these structures play a critical role in binding to cell-surface receptors. Systematic peptide screening is a powerful and logical method for identification of bioactive peptide sequences from multifunctional large molecules such as laminin.Here we describe a systematic peptide screening of the laminin α1 chain (positions 1–2110, not including the G domain) using a large set of overlapping peptides. We examined the cell attachment activities of 208 different peptides by two assay systems at the first stage of screening. Twenty five potential active sequences were identified and further evaluated for integrin binding and cell type specificity.DISCUSSIONPreviously we screened the G domain of the laminin α1 chain and identified several active sites using systematic synthetic peptides (20Nomizu M. Here we describe identification of cell binding sequences from the remainder of the laminin α1 chain (Fig. 8). We prepared 208 overlapping peptides and evaluated their cell binding activity with HT-1080 human fibrosarcoma cells using peptide-conjugated beads and peptide-coated plates. Eleven of the peptides showed cell attachment on both peptide-conjugated beads and peptide-coated plates. Five peptides showed cell attachment only to peptide-conjugated beads. These peptides may be have less binding ability to plastic plate and/or they cannot form active conformations on the plastic. Approximately 11% of the peptides (74 out of 673) were active in either the Sepharose bead assay or the peptide-coated plate assay. Of the peptides active in either assay, approximately a third (28 peptides) or 4% of the total peptides tested were active in both assays. More than half of the active peptides (31 peptides) were localized in the globular domains. The globular domains contain few cysteines and thus are relatively less conformationally stable than either the epidermal growth factor-like repeats located between some of the globular domains in the N termini or the coiled-coil domain located centrally in the α1 chain. The presence of the majority of the cell-binding sites in the globular domains may be due to the less rigid structures of these regions. Our data with the bead assay and the peptide-coated plate assay suggest the importance of conformations regulating cellular interactions. Since the test peptides were attached to the beads in solution versusdried on the dishes, it is likely that different conformations occurred. Inhibition of cell attachment on a laminin-1 substrate by peptides suggests that active sites of A-10, A-13, A-24, and A-25 are available on the intact molecule and that their activity is specific to laminin-1. These results confirm the importance of conformation for cell interactions.It is possible that some active sequences in laminin are always cryptic and are not exposed with different laminin-protein interactions. Systematic peptide screening is a powerful and logical method for identification of bioactive peptide sequences from multifunctional large molecules such as laminin. Here we describe a systematic peptide screening of the laminin α1 chain (positions 1–2110, not including the G domain) using a large set of overlapping peptides. We examined the cell attachment activities of 208 different peptides by two assay systems at the first stage of screening. Twenty five potential active sequences were identified and further evaluated for integrin binding and cell type specificity. Mixed lineage kinase-3 (MLK-3) is a mitogen-activated kinase kinase kinase that mediates stress-activating protein kinase (SAPK)/c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase activation. MLK-3 and other MLK family kinases are characterized by the presence of multiple protein-protein interaction domains including a tandem leucine/isoleucine zipper (LZs) motif. Leucine zippers are known to mediate protein dimerization raising the possibility that the tandem leucine/isoleucine zippers may function as a dimerization motif of MLK-3. Using both co-immunoprecipitation and nonreducing SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, we demonstrated that MLK-3 forms disulfide bridged homo-dimers and that the LZs motif is sufficient for MLK-3 homodimerization. We next asked whether MLK-3 utilizes a dimerization-based activation mechanism analogous to that of receptor tyrosine kinases. We found that dimerization via the LZs motif is a prerequisite for MLK-3 autophosphorylation. We then demonstrated that co-expression of Cdc42 lead to a substantial increase in MLK-3 dimerization, indicating that binding by this GTPase may induce MLK-3 dimerization. Moreover, the LZs minus form of MLK-3 failed to activate the downstream target SAPK, and expression of a MLK-3 LZs polypeptide was found to block SAPK activation by wild type MLK-3. Taken together, these findings indicate that dimerization plays a pivotal role in MLK-3 activation. Mixed lineage kinase-3 (MLK-3) is a mitogen-activated kinase kinase kinase that mediates stress-activating protein kinase (SAPK)/c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase activation. MLK-3 and other MLK family kinases are characterized by the presence of multiple protein-protein interaction domains including a tandem leucine/isoleucine zipper (LZs) motif. Leucine zippers are known to mediate protein dimerization raising the possibility that the tandem leucine/isoleucine zippers may function as a dimerization motif of MLK-3. Using both co-immunoprecipitation and nonreducing SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, we demonstrated that MLK-3 forms disulfide bridged homo-dimers and that the LZs motif is sufficient for MLK-3 homodimerization. We next asked whether MLK-3 utilizes a dimerization-based activation mechanism analogous to that of receptor tyrosine kinases. We found that dimerization via the LZs motif is a prerequisite for MLK-3 autophosphorylation. We then demonstrated that co-expression of Cdc42 lead to a substantial increase in MLK-3 dimerization, indicating that binding by this GTPase may induce MLK-3 dimerization. Moreover, the LZs minus form of MLK-3 failed to activate the downstream target SAPK, and expression of a MLK-3 LZs polypeptide was found to block SAPK activation by wild type MLK-3. Taken together, these findings indicate that dimerization plays a pivotal role in MLK-3 activation. mixed lineage kinase mitogen-activated protein kinase c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase stress-activating protein kinase leucine zipper-bearing kinase Cdc42 and Rac interactive binding glutathione S-transferase leucine zippers polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis dithiothreitol hemagglutinin.
