Wagner, were in L15 medium containing 500 μg/ml of active G418. Transient transfections of PC12cells and ND7 cells were performed using the calcium phosphate procedure as described by Gorman (26Gorman C.M. Glover D.M. DNA Cloning: A Practical Approach. IRL Press, Oxford, UK1985: 143-190Google Scholar). Transfections were carried out with 4 × 105 cells/well on six-well tissue culture plates. The amounts of expression plasmids used are indicated in the figure legends. For each transfection a β-galactosidase expression plasmid was used as an internal control. Following calcium phosphate transfections, PC12 cells were glycerol-shocked and incubated for 16 h in media containing 1% horse serum. Cells were then treated with 2.5sNGF, EGF, basic FGF, IL-6, TNF-α, IFN-γ, all-trans retinoic acid, and Bt2cAMP for 30 h. In some experiments, cells were pretreated with different protein kinase inhibitors for 1 h before addition of NGF and Bt2cAMP. Cells were then harvested and assayed for luciferase activities according to the manufacturer's directions (Promega). Results were normalized to β-galactosidase activity by using relative protein content as determined by Bradford protein assay (27Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (211946) Google Scholar). To determine whether the transcriptional activity of CBP is regulated by cellular signal cascades, we used a construct in which the full-length CBP was fused to the DNA binding domain of the yeast transcription factor GAL4 (21Swope D.L. Muller C.L. Chrivia J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 28138-28145Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Functional analysis of CBP demonstrated that CBP, as with other transcription coactivators, lacks a DNA binding domain (9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar). Previous studies have shown that Gal4-CBP fusion proteins can activate gene transcription when delivered to a promoter containing Gal4 DNA binding sites (9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar, 21Swope D.L. Muller C.L. Chrivia J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 28138-28145Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Thus the Gal4-CBP construct provides a good template for investigating regulation of CBP transcriptional activity. PC12 cells are derived from a rat pheochromocytoma and respond to a variety of external stimuli in different ways (23Greene L.A. Tischler A.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1976; 73: 2424-2428Crossref PubMed Scopus (4802) Google Scholar). This cell line offers a very useful model system for studying gene regulation induced by various cellular signal cascades in cells of neuronal origin. As a first step in identifying which extracellular stimuli can influence the transcriptional activity of CBP, we overexpressed the Gal4-CBP fusion proteins together with a reporter construct containing five Gal4 binding sites and the E1B TATA box (10Sun P. Enslen H. Myung P.S. Maurer R.A. Genes Dev. 1994; 8: 2527-2539Crossref PubMed Scopus (635) Google Scholar) in PC12 cells and then treated the cells with NGF, EGF, basic FGF, IL-6, TNF-α, IFN-γ, all-trans retinoic acid, or Bt2cAMP. As previously reported, Gal-CBP (full-length) stimulated transcription from the reporter gene 6-fold over the basal level. The DNA binding domain of Gal4 (amino acids 1–147) has been shown previously to be inactive in transcriptional stimulation, and this has been confirmed in our studies. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the activity of the Gal4 DNA binding domain was not induced by any extracelluar stimuli tested, indicating that any change of the transcriptional activity observed with the Gal4-CBP fusion proteins is due to the CBP portions. Treatment with growth factors including NGF, basic FGF, and EGF up-regulated the transcriptional activity of the full-length CBP with the strongest effect being observed with the NGF treatment (Fig. 1). Enhancement of the transcriptional activity of Gal4-CBP (full-length) protein was also observed upon cAMP and retinoic acid treatment. However, the transcriptional activity of CBP was not induced by treatment with cytokines including IL-6, TNF-α, and IFN-γ. When we substitute the CBP C-terminal activation domain (amino acids 1678–2441 fused to Gal4) for full-length CBP in this experiment, none of the up-regulation of the transcriptional activity of CBP was lost in response to NGF, FGF, EGF, cAMP, and retinoic acid. In fact, a stronger effect was observed with the C-terminal domain. This indicates that the C-terminal region (amino acids 1678–2441) of CBP contains sufficient information to be fully induced by these factors (Fig. 1). In contrast, the N-terminal activation domain of CBP (amino acids 1–460) showed no significant activation by any of the stimuli tested, indicating that it cannot mediate these effects (Fig. 1). Although these initial experiments used a NGF concentration of 50 ng/ml, we subsequently observed significant activation of the full-length and C-terminal CBP/Gal4 fusions by 25 ng/ml of NGF (data not shown), and this concentration was therefore used in subsequent assays. The effect of NGF on the CBP activity was not specific to the PC12 cell line because a similar up-regulation was observed with primary dorsal root ganglion neurons, which are responsive to NGF but not dependent upon NGF for survival (28Lindsay R.M. J. Neurosci. 1988; 8: 2394-2405Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) (data not shown). This experiment was also carried out in the ND7 cell line, which is derived from dorsal root ganglion neurons and lacks responsiveness to NGF but can respond to cAMP (24Wood J.N. Bevan S.J. Coote P. Darn P.M. Hogan P. Latchman D.S. Morrison C. Rougon G. Theveniau M. Wheatley S.C. Proc. R. Soc. London Ser. B Biol. Sci. 1990; 241: 187-194Crossref PubMed Scopus (219) Google Scholar). cAMP treatment up-regulated the transcriptional activity of CBP (data not shown). As expected, NGF showed no effects in this cell line. We next characterized NGF-activated signaling pathways required to up-regulate the transcriptional activity of CBP. PC12 cells respond to NGF by acquiring a reversible sympathetic neuronal like morphology that is preceded by a cycle of cell division. Several signal transduction pathways have been implicated in mediating the NGF-signaling including PKAs, PKC, and MAPKS (3Hama T. Huang K.-P. Guroff G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 86: 1756-1760Google Scholar, 4Schubert D. Heinemann S. Kidokoro Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 2579-2583Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar, 5Cowley S. Paterson H. Kemp P. Marshall C.J. Cell. 1994; 77: 841-852Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1844) Google Scholar). To investigate involvement of the PKA pathway in NGF-induced up-regulation of CBP activity, similar experiments were carried out in a PKA-deficient PC12 cell line, in which mutant regulatory subunits of PKA were stably expressed (25Ginty D.D. Glowacka D. DeFranco C. Wagner J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 15325-15333Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, this cell line is insensitive to stimulation by cAMP because cAMP-signaling is mediated via activation of PKA, which in turn phosphorylates cellular substrates (29Taylor S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 8443-8446Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As illustrated in Fig. 2 A, cAMP-induced up-regulation of the CBP activity was blocked in PKA-deficient PC12 cells, whereas NGF-mediated enhancement of the CBP activity was observed in these cells. Similarly, a specific PKA inhibitor, H-89, completely inhibited cAMP-stimulated up-regulation of CBP transcriptional activity but did not have this effect on NGF-induced CBP activity (Fig. 2 B). Taken together, the data suggest that NGF up-regulates the transcriptional activity of CBP via a signal pathway distinct from that activated by cAMP. The binding of nerve growth factor to its receptor is known to induce receptor dimerization, autophosphorylation, and the activation of phospholipase C, which in turn activates PKC. We next asked whether activation of PKC is required for NGF-induced enhancement of CBP transcriptional activity. As illustrated in Fig. 3, treatment of PC12 cells with a PKC activator, SC-9, or a selective PKC inhibitor, H-7, did not show significant effects either on NGF-induced up-regulation of CBP activity or on the constitutive activity of CBP. In addition, overexpression of a constitutive active subunit of PKC in PC12 cells failed to stimulate CBP activity. It is known that binding of NGF to its receptor tyrosine kinase activates the Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK pathway, which is also called MAPK pathway (30Marshall C.J. Cell. 1995; 80: 179-185Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (4212) Google Scholar). Recent studies revealed three distinct MAPK cascades: p42/p44MAPK, p38MAPK, and stress-activated protein kinases (SAPKs), also called Jun kinases (31Cano E. Mahadevan L.C. Trents Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 117-122Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (996) Google Scholar). To investigate the potential role of the p38MAPK signaling pathway in the NGF-mediated up-regulation of CBP activity, we have used the specific p38MAPK inhibitor, SB 203580. As shown in Fig. 4, NGF-mediated up-regulation of CBP activity was insensitive to the presence of SB 203580. Interestingly, in our initial experiments, we have found that the transcriptional activity of CBP is not regulated by stimulation by various cytokines (Fig. 1) whose signals are predominantly mediated by the activation of the p38MAPK and SAPKs. In addition, overexpression of SAPK-1 in conjunction with activation of this kinase by heat shock treatment of the cells at 42 °C for 1 h showed little effect on the transcriptional activity of CBP (Fig. 4). Taken together, these findings indicate that activation of p38MAPK and SAPKs neither up-regulates CBP activity nor mediates NGF-induced enhancement of the transcriptional activity. MAPK cascades channel extracellular signals into specific cellular responses. Activation of p42MAPK (ERK2) and p44MAPK (ERK1) mediate signals in response to growth factors (32Lenormand P. Sardet C. Pages G. L'Allemain G. Brunet A. Pouyssegur J. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 1079-1088Crossref PubMed Scopus (577) Google Scholar). Recent studies demonstrated that a synthetic compound, PD 098059, inhibited specifically the activation of MAPK (p42MAPK) by growth factors in vivo(33Dudley D.T. Pang L. Decker S.J. Bridges A.J. Saltiel A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 7686-7689Crossref PubMed Scopus (2581) Google Scholar). As illustrated in Fig. 5 A, PD 98059 inhibited NGF-induced up-regulation of CBP transcriptional activity in a dose-dependent manner. At the concentration of 50 μM in cell culture media, PD 98059 completely blocked the NGF-induced up-regulation of CBP activity. In addition, reduction of the basal transcription activity of Gal4-CBP fusion proteins was observed in response to treatment with PD 98059. In contrast, PD 98059 did not show any inhibition of the cAMP-induced enhancement of CBP activity (Fig. 5 B). These data suggest that activation of p42MAPK is involved in the NGF-induced up-regulation of transcriptional activity of CBP but not cAMP-mediated activation. To investigate the role of p42/44MAPK in the regulation of CBP activity more directly, we used previously characterized expression constructs to modulate either positively or negatively the p44MAPK activity (22Lavoie J.N. L'Allemain G. Brunet A. Muller R. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 20608-20616Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1069) Google Scholar). As illustrated in Fig. 6 A, the NGF-mediated up-regulation of the transcriptional activity of CBP was blocked by expression of dominant-negative p44MAPK (MAPKK1T192A). In addition, overexpression of a constitutively activated mutant of MAPK kinase (MKK1-SS/DD) led to up-regulation of the transcriptional activity of Gal4-CBP fusion proteins (Fig. 6 B). Taken together, these data indicate that activation of the p42MAPK/p44MAPK signaling pathway plays an important role in mediating NGF-induced up-regulation of the transcriptional activity of CBP. Thus, it is clear that the activation of the p42/p44MAPKpathway is responsible for NGF-induced up-regulation of the transcriptional activity of the full-length CBP and the C-terminal activation domain of CBP (amino acids 1678–2441). To localize regions in the C-terminal activation domain of CBP that mediate NGF-induced up-regulation, we used a series of smaller Gal-CBP chimera constructs spanning the C-terminal region (amino acids 1678–2441). In addition, two other CBP N-terminal regions (amino acids 227–460 and amino acids 721–1678) were also tested in this experiment. As illustrated in Fig. 7, two of these chimeras containing smaller C-terminal regions: Gal-CBP (amino acids (1961–2039) and Gal-CBP (amino acids 2060–2179) were each able to mediate a 7-fold increase in transactivation in response to NGF, whereas a much smaller effect or no effect at all was observed with the other C-terminal and N-terminal fragments. Hence the response to NGF can be mediated independently by two short regions of the C terminus that contain the two previously characterized C-terminal activation domains (21Swope D.L. Muller C.L. Chrivia J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 28138-28145Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). The specific MAPK inhibitor PD 98059 completely blocked NGF-induced up-regulation of transactivation by these two smaller activation domains (Fig. 8). Similarly, NGF-induced up-regulation of either domain was also inhibited by overexpression of dominant-negative p44MAPK (MAPKK1T192A) (Fig. 8). These data indicate that NGF can up-regulate the transcriptional activity of different C-terminal activation domains of CBP through activation of the p42/p44MAPK pathway.Figure 8Activation of the p42/p44MAPKpathway mediates up-regulation of activity of two smaller CBP C-terminal activation domains by NGF in PC12 cells. Luciferase assay results of co-transfecting PC12 cells with 2 μg of the Gal4-E1B TATA-luciferase with 2 μg of the Gal4 DNA binding domain expression plasmid or the same vector containing CBP C-terminal regions (amino acids 1961–2039 or 2060–2179) with either 2 μg of the empty expression vector or the same vector containing the MAPK inhibitory mutant (T192A). The specific MAPK inhibitor PD98059 (50 μM) was added 1 h before addition of NGF (25 ng/ml). Values are expressed relative to the level of luciferase in untreated PC12 cells transfected with the empty expression vector (set at 100%) and are the means of three independent transfection experiments whose standard deviation is shown by the error bars.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Following the identification of CBP, extensive studies have been carried out to investigate the functional properties of CBP. It is well known that CBP is a transcription coactivator for a number of different transcription factors (for review see Ref. 12Shikama N. Lyon J. Thangue N.B. Trends Cell Biol. 1997; 17: 230-236Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (424) Google Scholar). Fusion of the CBP cDNA to a heterologous DNA binding domain demonstrates that CBP contains potent transcriptional activation domains (9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar). This transcriptional activity has been demonstrated to reside in the C-terminal region of the molecule. Here we show that transactivation mediated by the C-terminal activation domain of CBP (amino acids 1678–2441) can be up-regulated by NGF as well as by cAMP. The finding that cAMP can stimulate CBP activity is in accord with a previous study demonstrating that overexpression of PKA in the cells enhanced the transcriptional activity of CBP (9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar). Previous studies revealed that NGF can regulate CREB activity by inducing phosphorylation of CREB and interaction with CBP (6Ginty D.D. Bonni A. Greenberg M.E. Cell. 1994; 77: 713-725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (673) Google Scholar, 9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar). However, regulation of CBP activity in response to NGF was not reported before. We have demonstrated here that NGF up-regulates the transcriptional activity of CBP via a signal pathway distinct from the cAMP pathway (PKA-dependent pathway). Furthermore, activation of PKC, p38MAPK, and Jun kinases are unlikely to be involved in the up-regulation of CBP activity. In contrast to cAMP, which up-regulates CBP activity via the PKA pathway, NGF was shown to up-regulate the transcriptional activity of CBP via activation of the p42/p44MAPK pathway. Nakajima et al. (34Nakajima T. Fukamizu A. Takahashi J. Gage F.H. Fisher T. Blenis J. Montminy M.R. Cell. 1996; 86: 465-474Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar) have observed that NGF can induce formation of the pp90rsk-CBP complex and NGF-mediated activation of the c-fos promoter requires interaction of CBP with pp90rsk. It has been suggested that the pp90rsk-CBP complex, which appears to be essential for induction of NGF-responsive gene, may function via inducing a productive interaction between CBP and serum response element binding proteins (34Nakajima T. Fukamizu A. Takahashi J. Gage F.H. Fisher T. Blenis J. Montminy M.R. Cell. 1996; 86: 465-474Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). Interestingly, pp90rsk is a component of a Ras-MAPK signaling pathway that mediates NGF signaling (20Zhang J. Vinkemeier U. Gu W. Chakravarti D. Horvath C. Darnell J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 15092-15096Crossref PubMed Scopus (418) Google Scholar). We report here that another component of the ras-MAPK signal pathway, p42/p44MAPK, can functionally interact with CBP and mediate NGF-induced up-regulation of the transcriptional activity of CBP. Our results indicate that the functional interaction of p42/p44MAPK with CBP occurs through several distinct sites within amino acids 1961–2039 and 2069–2179 of CBP, whereas pp90rsk has been shown to interact with amino acids 1805–1891 of CBP (34Nakajima T. Fukamizu A. Takahashi J. Gage F.H. Fisher T. Blenis J. Montminy M.R. Cell. 1996; 86: 465-474Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). Most commonly, regulation of transcription factor activity by extracellular signals is achieved by reversible phosphorylation (35Hill C.S. Treisman R. Cell. 1995; 80: 199-211Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1194) Google Scholar). Thus, NGF regulates CBP activity, possibly through stimulating CBP phosphorylation by activated p42/p44MAPK and pp90rsk in cells. It is possible that interaction between CBP and pp90rsk leads to phosphorylation of CBP, which in turn induces the interaction between CBP and other proteins. However, the region of CBP that interacts with pp90rsk is localized to the region of amino acids 1805–1891, which does not contain the pp90rsk consensus phosphorylation site (Ser1772) (34Nakajima T. Fukamizu A. Takahashi J. Gage F.H. Fisher T. Blenis J. Montminy M.R. Cell. 1996; 86: 465-474Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). Thus, it is unlikely that formation of the pp90rsk-CBP complex may induce phosphorylation of CBP at Ser1772. Whatever the effect of formation of the pp90rsk-CBP complex on CBP, it is possible that functional interaction between p42/p44MAPK with CBP may stimulate CBP phosphorylation. Indeed, several potential MAPK recognition sites are present in the C-terminal region (amino acids 1678–2441) of CBP. In addition, we found that transactivation mediated by two smaller CBP C-terminal regions (amino acids 1961–2039 and 2060–2179) was up-regulated by activation of p42/p44MAPK in response to NGF treatment, suggesting that phosphorylation can occur at different sites throughout the C-terminal region. Interestingly, a recent study has shown that two adjacent C-terminal regions of CBP can be phosphorylated by MAPKsin vitro (36Janknecht R. Nordheim A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 228: 831-837Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). Further mapping is currently underway to precisely determine the sites that are phosphorylated by MAPKs. Studies have revealed that phosphorylation of a number of transcription factors at specific phosphoacceptor sites located within their activation domains correlates with increased transcriptional activity (for review see Ref. 37Hunter T. Karin M. Cell. 1992; 70: 375-387Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1115) Google Scholar). It was postulated that phosphorylation of activation domains induces conformational changes, which facilitates their interaction with the basal transcriptional machinery (or coactivator proteins) or decreases their interaction with corepressors. The C-terminal activation domain of CBP has been demonstrated to interact with components of the basal transcriptional machinery such as TFIIB (11Kwok R.P.S. Lundblad J.R. Chrivia J.C. Richards J.P. Bachinger H.P. Brennan R.G. Roberts S.G.E. Green M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1994; 370: 223-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (1275) Google Scholar) and the RNA polymerase holoenzyme complex as well as the transcriptional co-activator p/CIP (38Kee B.L. Arias J. Montminy M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271 (Nature 376, 348–351): 2373-2375Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar, 39Torchia J. Rose D.W. Inostroza J. Kamel Y. Westin S. Glass C.K. Rosenfeld M.G. Nature. 1997; 387: 677-684Crossref PubMed Scopus (1101) Google Scholar). These interactions may be regulated by CBP phosphorylation. It will be of interest to determine whether NGF, which up-regulates the transcriptional activity of CBP, enhances these interactions. NGF and FGF cause PC12 cells to differentiate to a sympathetic-like neuronal phenotype through the MAPK signal pathway (5Cowley S. Paterson H. Kemp P. Marshall C.J. Cell. 1994; 77: 841-852Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1844) Google Scholar), whereas the EGF induces proliferation instead of differentiation, but the EGF receptor also activates MAPK signaling (40Qiu M-S. Green S.H. Neuron. 1991; 7: 937-946Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). Thus, it is not surprising to see that FGF and EGF also up-regulate the transcriptional activity of CBP. Presumably, like NGF, FGF and EGF enhance CBP activity via activation of the p42/p44MAPK pathway. Hence, the transcriptional activity of the CBP C-terminal activation domain can be regulated by various extracellular stimuli including NGF, FGF, EGF, cAMP, and retinoic acid but not by cytokines, indicating that extracellular signals induce specific gene transcription by differentially phosphorylating CBP, which play an active role both in the integration of cellular signal pathways and in activation of gene transcription. CBP, which is initially characterized as a co-activator for genes that are responsive to cyclic AMP (9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar), has been shown to be a general mediator of signal-dependent transcription. In response to various stimuli including cyclic AMP, growth factors, cytokines, stress, steroid and thyroid hormones, or retinoids, CBP associates with a variety of signal-dependent transcription factors including CREB (9Chrivia J.C. Kwok R.P. Lamb N. Hagiwala M. Montminy M.R. Goodman R.H. Nature. 1993; 365: 855-859Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar), jun (16Arias J. Alberts A. Brinde P. Claret F. Smeal T. Karin M. Feramisco J. Montminy M. Nature. 1994; 370: 226-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (679) Google Scholar), fos (17Bannister A.J. Kouzarides T. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 4758-4762Crossref PubMed Scopus (319) Google Scholar), STATs 1 and 2 (18Bhattacharya S. Eckner R. Grossman S. Oldread E. Arany Z. D'Andrea A. Livingston D. Nature. 1996; 383: 344-347Crossref PubMed Scopus (417) Google Scholar), or nuclear hormone receptors (19Chakravarti D. LaMorte V. Nelson M. Nakajima T. Schulman I. Juguilon H. Montminy M. Evans R. Nature. 1996; 383: 99-103Crossref PubMed Scopus (839) Google Scholar), respectively. Interaction between CBP and these signal-dependent factors tethers CBP to the promoters of signal-responsive genes, resulting in activation of gene transcription. Our results showed that the transcriptional activity of CBP was regulated differentially in response to different extracellular stimuli. Thus, CBP itself may represent a potential target of various cellular signal cascades as well as a mediator of signal-dependent transcription. The data presented here show that the transcriptional activity of CBP can be up-regulated in response to NGF. This finding indicates that CBP, like its partner CREB, is a key target of the NGF-stimulated signaling pathway. NGF has been shown to induce differentiation of PC12 cells in part by stimulating the transcription of specific genes including c-fos (41Greenberg M. Greene L. Ziff E. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 14101-14110Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CBP has been shown to be essential for transcriptional induction of c-fos by NGF (16Arias J. Alberts A. Brinde P. Claret F. Smeal T. Karin M. Feramisco J. Montminy M. Nature. 1994; 370: 226-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (679) Google Scholar, 34Nakajima T. Fukamizu A. Takahashi J. Gage F.H. Fisher T. Blenis J. Montminy M.R. Cell. 1996; 86: 465-474Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). Interestingly, our previous study showed that the NGF inducibility of the calcitonin/calcitonin gene-related peptide promoter is dependent upon the cyclic AMP response element and is associated with the NGF-stimulated phosphorylation of CREB on Ser133, which in turn induces interaction of CREB with its coactivator CBP (8Watson A. Latchman D.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9655-9660Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Thus, CBP plays an important role in the activation of the calcitonin/calcitonin gene-related peptide promoter by NGF via at least two mechanisms. One mechanism is that it is recruited to the promoter via interaction with CREB. Another mechanism is that its transcriptional activity is directly enhanced by the NGF-induced activation of the p42/p44MAPK cascade. We thank Dr. J. Wagner for the gift of the PKA-deficient PC12 cells, Dr. R. A. Maurer for the gift of the reporter plasmid 5xGal4-E1B TATA-luciferase, Dr. P. Parker for the gift of the PKC active subunit construct, Dr. J. Pouyssegur for the gift of the MAPKK active mutant (SS/DD) and the dominant-negative p44MAPK mutant (T192A) plasmids, and Dr. B. Williams for EGF. We also acknowledge Dr. N. S. Thomas for helpful discussions and critical comments.

The location of origins of DNA replication within the Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome is primarily determined by the origin recognition complex (ORC) interacting with specific DNA sequences. The analogous situation in vertebrate cells is far less clear, although ORC subunits have been identified in several vertebrate organisms including Xenopus laevis. Monoclonal antibodies were raised against Xenopus Orc1p and used for single-step immunoaffinity purification of the entire ORC from an egg extract. Six polypeptides (∼110, 68, 64, 48, 43, and 27 kDa) copurified withXenopus Orc1p. Protein sequencing also showed the 64-kDa protein to be the previously identified Xenopus Orc2p. Microsequencing of the 43- and 48-kDa proteins that copurified with Orc1p and Orc2p led to their identification as the Orc4p and Orc5p subunits, respectively. Peptide sequences from the 43-kDa protein also allowed the isolation of cDNAs encoding the Xenopus, mouse, and human ORC4 subunits. Human ORC5 was also cloned; its sequence displayed extensive homology to bothDrosophila and yeast ORC5. Surprisingly, comparison of the amino acid sequences of Orc1p, Orc4p, and Orc5p suggests that they are structurally related to each other and to the replication initiation protein, Cdc6p. Finally, we present the sequence of the putative Xenopus and human Orc3p. The initiation of DNA replication in eukaryotes is tightly regulated such that all the DNA is replicated precisely once per cell cycle from a number of discrete replication origins (Refs. 1Cairns J. J. Mol. Biol. 1966; 15: 372-373Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 2Huberman J.A. Riggs A.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1966; 55: 599-606Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 3Rao P.N. Johnson R.T. Nature. 1970; 225: 159-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (528) Google Scholar; for reviews, see Refs. 4Diffley J.F.X. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 2819-2830Crossref PubMed Scopus (211) Google Scholar and 5Stillman B. Science. 1996; 274: 1659-1664Crossref PubMed Scopus (428) Google Scholar). The nature of this regulation, however, is not well understood as only a small fraction of proteins involved in this process have been identified. Moreover, with the exception of budding yeast, the DNA sequences that define the origin of DNA replication on chromosomes remain an almost complete mystery in higher eukaryotes. Present knowledge of the control over initiation of DNA replication in an eukaryotic cell is largely based on experiments done in the yeastSaccharomyces cerevisiae. In this yeast, DNA replication starts from well defined origins, known as the autonomously replicating sequences (6Newlon C.S. Theis J.F. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1994; 3: 752-758Crossref Scopus (195) Google Scholar). An essential, bipartite DNA sequence in all S. cerevisiae replication origins is recognized by the six-subunit origin recognition complex (ORC),1 which is itself essential for initiation of DNA replication (7Bell S.P. Stillman B. Nature. 1992; 357: 128-134Crossref PubMed Scopus (983) Google Scholar, 8Marahrens Y. Stillman B. Science. 1992; 255: 817-823Crossref PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar, 9Bell S.P. The nature of the DNA sequence specificity for origin function has not been resolved in species other than the budding yeast, but we imagine that characterization of ORC and its interaction with DNA will help clarify this situation. In pursuance of this goal, we sought to identify the protein subunits of ORC from Xenopus and human cells. Monoclonal antibodies against Xenopus Orc1p were made and used for immunoaffinity purification of the presumed, complete ORC protein complex from Xenopus egg extract. The purifiedXenopus ORC was composed of six subunits with molecular masses of ∼110, 68, 64, 48, 43, and 27 kDa. The 110- and 64-kDa proteins were identified previously as the Xenopus Orc1p and Orc2p proteins, respectively. We identified the 43-kDa protein as theXenopus homologue of the yeast Orc4p, and the 48-kDa polypeptide as the homologue of Orc5p. Based on this protein sequence information, cDNAs encoding the human Orc4p and Orc5p were also isolated. The sequences reveal a previously unrecognized structural similarity among the ORC subunits. Mice were injected with bacterially expressed full-length Xenopus Orc1p as described (33Harlow E. Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar). Spleen cells from three best-responding mice were used to generate antibody-producing hybridomas, and antibodies were screened by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay and immunoprecipitation (33Harlow E. Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar). Two deletional mutants of Xenopus Orc1p, ΔN 280 and ΔN 423, were use to map the epitopes of selected antibodies. Antibodies TK1 and TK15 were found to recognize epitopes within the first 280 residues, whereas TK37 and TK47 recognize a protein sequence between residue 423 and the C terminus of Xenopus Orc1p. Polyclonal antibodies against bacterially expressed full-lengthXenopus Orc1p and Orc2p were raised as described in (33Harlow E. Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar). Lane D. Antibodies: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1988Google Scholar. To perform immunoaffinity purification, antibody-coupled beads were incubated with Xenopus egg extract. The beads were then washed several times with ice-cold purification buffer (50 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 2.5 mm EDTA, 2.5 mm EGTA, and 0.5 mm dithiothreitol). The purified proteins were released by boiling in Laemmli sample buffer. Two procedures, Edman degradation method and mass spectrometry were used to microsequence the isolatedXenopus peptides. The first procedure was performed essentially as described in (9Bell S.P. Kobayashi R. Stillman B. Science. 1993; 262: 1844-1849Crossref PubMed Scopus (366) Google Scholar). Very briefly, proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and in-gel digested with lysyl-endopeptidase (Achromabacter protease I; Wako Chemical). Peptide fragments were subsequently extracted and separated on a Hewlett-Packard HPLC model 1090 using a Vydac C18 column. Separated peptides were sequenced with an automated protein sequencer (Applied Biosystems model 494). In the second procedure, the proteins were electroblotted and digested with trypsin (Boehringer Mannheim), and the peptides were extracted with 1:1 v/v formic acid:ethanol (34Sutton C.W. Pemberton K.S. Cottrell J.S. Corbett J.M. Wheeler C.H. Dunn M.J. Pappin D.J.C. Electrophoresis. 1995; 16: 308-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Cottrell J.S. Corbett J.M. Wheeler C.H. Dunn M.J. Pappin D.J.C. Electrophoresis. 1995; 16: 308-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 993-1002Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar), and the bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE. Fig. 1 shows that all four anti-Orc1p mAbs selectively immunoprecipitated a protein corresponding to the size of Orc1p, easily visible by Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining, whereas the control antibody did not (Fig. 1 A). Five additional polypeptides also reproducibly associated with all four anti-Orc1p antibodies but not with the control antibody (Fig. 1 A, arrows). Immunoblotting the same samples with an anti-Orc1p polyclonal antibody confirmed that the 110-kDa polypeptide was indeedXenopus Orc1p and an anti-Orc2p polyclonal antibody identified the 64-kDa polypeptide as Xenopus Orc2p (Fig. 1 B, lanes 3–6). It seemed likely, therefore, that the four proteins that copurified with the Xenopus Orc1p and Orc2p were components of Xenopus ORC. It is striking that the molecular masses of the ORC subunits purified from Xenopuseggs (∼110, 68, 64, 48, 43, and 27 kDa) corresponded closely to those of the ORC purified from Drosophila embryos (∼115, 82, 79, 47, 42, and 30 kDa), whereas the ORC identified in yeast was somewhat different (120, 72, 62, 56, 53, and 50 kDa) (7Bell S.P. Open table in a new tab A 473-base pair fragment from the mouse ORC4 cDNA clone was also used to screen a λ-ZAP Xenopus ovary cDNA library. Two identical clones containing a 1.3-kilobase ORF were identified. Importantly, more microsequencing of the 43-kDa polypeptide by both Edman degradation and mass spectrometry subsequently identified peptides (Table I) that showed close matches to the predicted sequence from the cDNA (Fig. 2). Several observations can be made upon aligning multiple Orc4p sequences from human, mouse, frog, and yeast (Fig. 2). First of all, all these sequences share similar lengths and are highly related to each other. A BLAST search comparing HsOrc4p with other sequences in GenBank showed that HsOrc4p is most related to MmOrc4p and XlOrc4p (P= 3.1e-251 for MmOrc4p, and P = 2.0e-204 for XlOrc4p). Not surprisingly, Orc4p from these intimately related organisms (human, mouse, and frog) share higher levels of homology (compare withP = 3.1e-24 for ScOrc4p). Second, multiple blocks of conserved residues can be readily identified. One intriguing feature is a strong match to the nucleotide binding site consisting of both the Walker A and B motifs (45Walker J.E. Saraste M. Runswick M.J. Gay N.J. EMBO J. 1982; 1: 945-951Crossref PubMed Scopus (4212) Google Scholar). This bipartite putative nucleotide binding site appears to be well conserved among human, mouse, and frog, whereas only a weak match to the Walker A motif, but not to the B motif, is found in ScOrc4p (Fig. 2). It has been postulated that the Walker A motif is involved in ATP/GTP binding, whereas the Walker B motif is involved in ATP hydrolysis (45Walker J.E. Saraste M. Runswick M.J. Gay N.J. EMBO J. 1982; 1: 945-951Crossref PubMed Scopus (4212) Google Scholar). In agreement with this, ScOrc4p has been shown to cross-link ATP in the presence of autonomously replicating sequence 1 and ScOrc1p (46Klemm R.D. Austin R.J. Bell S.P. Cell. 1997; 88: 493-502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar). However, mutations that removed this motif in ScOrc4p showed no gross phenotypic defect. Furthermore, the cross-linking to ATP was completely abrogated when the Walker A motif in Orc1p was mutated, indicating that the Orc4p-ATP binding might have been indirect or that it at least requires a functional ScOrc1p. It is likely that the nucleotide binding motif is nonfunctional in yeast but fully functional in higher eukaryotes due to selection pressure. Further biochemical analysis is necessary to address this question. A data base search identified a human EST clone, AA353934, as a potential homologue of theDrosophila Orc5p (DmOrc5p). This cDNA was sequenced entirely on both strands, and a conceptual translation with the most 5′-terminal ATG as tentative initiation codon revealed an ORF strikingly similar to both DmOrc5p (25Gossen M. Pak D.T.S. Hansen S.K. Acharya J.K. Botchan M.R. Science. 1995; 270: 1674-1677Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar) and the S. cerevisiae Orc5p (ScOrc5p; 15); this ORF will henceforth be referred to as HsOrc5p. Others have also identified this same EST clone encoding HsOrc5p (47Ishiai M. Dean F.B. Okumura K. Abe M. Moon K.-Y. Amin A.A. Kagotani K. Taguchi H. Murakami Y. Hanaoka F. O'Donnell M. Hurwitz J. Eki T. Genomics. 1997; 46: 294-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The predicted protein consists of 435 amino acids with a calculated molecular mass of ∼50 kDa. Overall, HsOrc5p is approximately 39% identical and 50% similar to DmOrc5p (Fig. 3). It is also 29% identical and 41% similar to ScOrc5p, with the sequence similarity most evident in the C-terminal half of the proteins. Nonetheless, a search of the PROSITE data base failed to identify any recognizable motif in this region. In the N terminus, all three proteins contain a putative Walker A motif, implicating a role of Orc5p in ATP binding. Indeed, ScOrc5p, when complexed with the other ORC subunits, displayed a DNA-independent ATP binding activity that was sensitive to mutations within the consensus (46Klemm R.D. Austin R.J. Bell S.P. Cell. 1997; 88: 493-502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar). Additional evidence supporting a role for this gene product as the human homologue of Orc5p was obtained from microsequencing the 48-kDa band that copurified with XlOrc1p and XlOrc2p. Several peptides were generated from this band (Table I; Fig. 3), all of which displayed extensive similarities to the deduced sequence of HsOrc5p, as well as DmOrc5p and ScOrc5p. Thus, the 48-kDa polypeptide that co-immunoprecipitated with XlOrc1p was most likely to be XlOrc5p. In a survey of primary human tissues using HsOrc5 mRNA as a probe, a single 1.9-kilobase transcript, was detected by Northern blotting in most tissues (data not shown). The size of the HsOrc5 transcript detected in this experiment suggested that the isolated cDNA was likely to be full-length. Intriguingly, HsORC5 mRNA was particularly abundant in testis (data not shown). A bacterial artif

UDP-GlcNAc acyltransferase (LpxA), the first enzyme of lipid A biosynthesis, catalyzes the transfer of an acyl chain activated on acyl carrier protein (ACP) to UDP-GlcNAc. LpxAs are very selective for the lengths of their acyl donor substrates. Escherichia coli LpxA prefers R-3-hydroxymyristoyl-ACP to R-3-hydroxydecanoyl-ACP by a factor of approximately 1000, whereas Pseudomonas aeruginosa LpxA prefers the opposite. E. coli G173M LpxA and the reciprocal P. aeruginosa M169G LpxA show reversed substrate selectivity in vitro and in vivo, demonstrating the existence of precise hydrocarbon rulers in LpxAs.

The upstream open reading frame (uORF) in the 5′ leader of the mammalian mRNA encodingS-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase (AdoMetDC) serves as a negative regulatory element by suppressing translation of the associated downstream cistron. Certain changes in the amino acid sequence of the hexapeptide (sequence MAGDIS) encoded by the uORF destroy suppressive activity, implying specific interaction with a cellular target. In this paper, we examine the extent of alterations that can be tolerated in this uORF. The mammalian AdoMetDCuORF inhibits downstream translation when placed into the 5′ leader of a yeast mRNA with characteristics resembling those in mammalian cells, suggesting that the encoded peptide has a similar target across species. Using yeast for the initial screen, we tested the specificity of the critical three codons at the 3′ end of the uORF by saturation mutagenesis. Altered uORFs selected from the primary yeast screen were then retested in mammalian cells. The requirements at codons 4 and 5 were quite stringent; only aspartic acid at codon 4 yielded a fully suppressive peptide, and only valine could substitute productively for isoleucine at codon 5. The specificity at codon 6 was much looser, with many substitutions retaining suppressive activity in both yeast and mammalian cells. Certain changes in the amino acid sequence of the hexapeptide (sequence MAGDIS) encoded by the uORF destroy suppressive activity, implying specific interaction with a cellular target. In this paper, we examine the extent of alterations that can be tolerated in this uORF. The mammalian AdoMetDCuORF inhibits downstream translation when placed into the 5′ leader of a yeast mRNA with characteristics resembling those in mammalian cells, suggesting that the encoded peptide has a similar target across species. Using yeast for the initial screen, we tested the specificity of the critical three codons at the 3′ end of the uORF by saturation mutagenesis. Altered uORFs selected from the primary yeast screen were then retested in mammalian cells. The requirements at codons 4 and 5 were quite stringent; only aspartic acid at codon 4 yielded a fully suppressive peptide, and only valine could substitute productively for isoleucine at codon 5. The specificity at codon 6 was much looser, with many substitutions retaining suppressive activity in both yeast and mammalian cells. upstream open reading frame human growth hormone. The occurrence of open reading frames in the 5′ leaders of eukaryotic mRNA molecules is quite rare. These upstream open reading frames (uORFs)1 are found in less than 10% of cloned mammalian mRNAs; however, the small subset of genes that do contain uORFs is strongly biased toward those encoding growth-related products such as growth factors, growth factor receptors, tumor suppressors, and regulated transcription factors (1Geballe A.P. Morris D.R. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 159-164Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar, 2Morris D.R. Prog. Nucleic Acid Res. Mol. Biol. 1995; 51: 339-363Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 3Geballe A.P. Hershey J.W.B. Mathews M.B. Sonenberg N. Translational Control. Cold Spring Harbor Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1996: 173-198Google Scholar, 4Morris D.R. Harford J.B. Morris D.R. RNA Metabolism and Post-transcriptional Gene Regulation. Wiley-Liss, Inc., New York1997: 165-180Google Scholar). It is striking that over two-thirds of the proto-oncogene mRNAs surveyed 10 years ago contained uORFs (5Kozak M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 15: 8125-8148Crossref PubMed Scopus (4168) Google Scholar). These observations, associating uORFs with regulation of vertebrate cell growth, suggest that these elements of mRNA structure may be involved in aspects of translational control known to be a part of the mitogenic program (2Morris D.R. Prog. Nucleic Acid Res. Mol. Biol. 1995; 51: 339-363Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). For a uORF to participate in translational regulation it must itself be translated, and its translation in turn must suppress, in a regulated manner, translation of the cistron located downstream (2Morris D.R. Prog. Nucleic Acid Res. Mol. Biol. 1995; 51: 339-363Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 4Morris D.R. Harford J.B. Morris D.R. RNA Metabolism and Post-transcriptional Gene Regulation. Wiley-Liss, Inc., New York1997: 165-180Google Scholar). Some uORFs, but not all, strongly suppress translation of the downstream cistron. At least two structural features are known to contribute to the suppressiveness of a uORF in eukaryotic cells, the RNA sequence flanking the termination codon and the amino acid sequence of the encoded peptide (1Geballe A.P. Morris D.R. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 159-164Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar, 2Morris D.R. Prog. Nucleic Acid Res. Mol. Biol. 1995; 51: 339-363Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 3Geballe A.P. Hershey J.W.B. Mathews M.B. Sonenberg N. Translational Control. Cold Spring Harbor Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1996: 173-198Google Scholar). In the yeast GCN4 gene, there are two suppressive uORFs in the 5′ leader (6Hinnebusch A.G. Hershey J.W.B. Mathews M.B. Sonenberg N. Translational Control. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1996: 199-244Google Scholar). The suppressiveness of theGCN4 uORFs is not determined by the sequence of the encoded peptides but by the G + C content of the RNA sequence surrounding the termination codon (7Grant C.M. Hinnebusch A.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 606-618Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). This led to the hypothesis that stable RNA-RNA interactions in the vicinity of the stop codon may result in suppression of downstream translation. In a second class of suppressive uORFs, referred to as “sequence-dependent uORFs,” suppressive activity depends on the amino acid sequence of the encoded peptide (1Geballe A.P. Morris D.R. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 159-164Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar). Examples from this class are limited, but the best studied are in the mammalian AdoMetDC gene (8Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21886-21893Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 726-731Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and the human cytomegalovirus gpUL4 (gp48) gene (10Schleiss M.R. Degnin C.R. Geballe A.P. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 6782-6789Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Degnin C.R. Schleiss M.R. Cao J.H. Geballe A.P. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 5514-5521Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In both instances, particular missense mutations of the codons at the 3′ end of the uORF abolish inhibitory activity, whereas modifications that retain the wild type amino acid coding information (synonymous mutations) uniformly preserve the suppressive effect of these uORFs. Because the sequence-dependent uORFs seem to act in cis on the ribosome that translated them (9Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 726-731Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Degnin C.R. Schleiss M.R. Cao J.H. Geballe A.P. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 5514-5521Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), a likely model is that the nascent peptide translated from the uORF interacts specifically with a component of the translation apparatus, such as peptidyltransferase, the peptide channel of the ribosome, or one of the termination factors, to stall the ribosome in the vicinity of the termination codon. The stalled ribosome thereby creates a blockade to further translation of the mRNA (1Geballe A.P. Morris D.R. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 159-164Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar). Consistent with this model, Cao and Geballe (12Cao J. Geballe A.P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 603-608Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar) have located a ribosome arrested over the termination codon of the wild type, but not mutant, uORF of thegpUL4(gp48) gene. The nature of the interaction between the encoded peptide and its target seems to be of paramount importance in defining the mechanism of inhibition by the sequence-dependent uORFs. The specificity of this interaction has not yet been examined systematically and in detail for any of the sequence-dependent uORFs. It is interesting to note that there is no similarity between the peptides encoded by the uORFs from the AdoMetDC and gpUL4(gp48) genes, implying that there are multiple intracellular targets for these regulatory molecules. In the studies described in this paper, we find that the specificity of this peptide-target interaction is widely conserved in nature, because the sequence-dependent inhibitory activity of the mammalianAdoMetDC uORF is retained when placed in a yeast 5′ leader. Using a yeast expression system as the primary screen, we examine by saturation mutagenesis the range of amino acids that can be substituted in critical positions of the AdoMetDC uORF with retention of suppressive activity. Substitutions of interest were retested in mammalian cells. The results show an exquisite dependence on amino acid sequence in that only aspartic acid is functional at position 4 in the peptide, and only valine will substitute for isoleucine at position 5. These results support the hypothesis of a highly specific interaction between the peptide encoded by the AdoMetDC uORF and its intracellular target. Chem. 1996; 271: 29576-29582Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Stable transfection of HeLa cells was performed by seeding 150-mm dishes with 1 × 106 cells, culturing overnight, adding fresh culture medium (adjusted to pH 7.2 by the addition of 1m Hepes, pH 7.2), and culturing an additional 4 h. Greene and Wiley Interscience, New York1993Google Scholar) and layered onto the monolayers of HeLa cells. After culturing overnight, the cells were exposed for 4 min to medium containing 15% glycerol, and fresh medium was added for beginning G-418 selection. For analysis of hGH expression, cultures of pooled clones were grown without G-418 for 48 h. The cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline (2 mm KCl, 1.5 mmKH2PO4, 140 mm NaCl, 8 mm Na2HPO4) supplemented with 10% calf serum and replaced with warm preconditioned culture medium. Preconditioned medium was obtained from nontransfected HeLa cultures grown at low density for 16 h. Samples of the medium were removed immediately (T 0) and after culturing for 6 h (T 6). Also at 6 h, the cells were lysed for extraction of RNA. Measurement of hGH protein accumulation (T 6–T 0) and Northern blot analysis were performed as outlined above. Random mutagenesis at codons 4 and 5 were performed as described above, using the same primer with the following oligonucleotides: 5′-ATCGTATTAAAAGCTTAGTATGGCCGGCGACNNNAGCTAGATCTTTCCGTAACG-3′ and 5′-ATCGTATTAAAAGCTTAGTATGGCCGGCGACATTNNNTAGATCTTTCCGTAAG-3′. Fractionation of yeast polysomes and isolation of RNA contained in the fractions was carried out using a modification of a published protocol (20Baim S.B. Pietras D.F. Eustice D.C. Sherman F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1985; 5: 1839-1846Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Briefly, 100-ml cultures in mid-log phase of growth were poured over approximately 75 g of crushed, frozen culture medium, and the mixture was swirled in an ice water bath for 10 min. The cells were collected by centrifugation at 4 °C and washed twice with 10 ml of polysome lysis buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 100 mm NaCl, 30 mm MgCl2, 500 μg of heparin/ml, and 0.2 μl of diethyl pyrocarbonate/ml). The cells were disrupted in 1.5 ml of polysome lysis buffer containing 2 g of acid-washed glass beads (425–600 μm; Sigma) by eight cycles of vortexing for 15 s followed by incubation on ice for 45 s. The lysate was decanted from the beads and centrifuged for 5 min at 12,000 ×g. The lysate was layered on top of a 7–47% (w/v) sucrose gradient and centrifuged at 39,000 rpm in a Beckman SW-40 rotor for 1 h at 4 °C. Gradients were separated into 12 equal fractions using a density gradient fractionator model 185 (Isco, Lincoln, NE) while monitoring absorbance at 254 nm. Each fraction was precipitated by adding 3 volumes of 100% ethanol, and the resulting pellets were resuspended in 450 μl of RNA isolation buffer (20 mmTris-HCl, pH 7.5, 2.5 mm EDTA, 100 mm NaCl, and 0.1% SDS). After the addition of 45 μl of 2 m sodium acetate, the samples were extracted once with water-saturated phenol, once with phenol-chloroform (1:1), and once with chloroform. RNA was precipitated with ethanol and analyzed for β-galactosidase mRNA by RNase protection as described above. Yeast cultures containing the indicated constructs were grown to mid-log phase and sevenA 600 units were washed once with fresh medium and resuspended in fresh medium at A 600 = 1.0. The cells were labeled by the addition of 33 μCi/ml [35S]methionine (NEN Life Science Products). After incubation for 60 min with shaking at 30 °C, cultures were poured into centrifuge tubes containing 10 mm NaN3 and 10 mm KF and harvested by centrifugation. After washing the cells once in unlabeled medium, cell pellets were resuspended in 700 μl of SDS lysis buffer (1% SDS, 50 mm dithiothreitol, 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, and 1 mm EDTA), and an equal volume of 425–600-μm acid-washed glass beads (Sigma) was added. After vortexing for 8 cycles as described above, the lysates were cleared by centrifuging for 5 min at 12,000 × g, and the supernatant solutions were heated at 100 °C for 5 min. Aliquots from each sample were precipitated with trichloroacetic acid and counted in a liquid scintillation counter. Samples containing equal precipitable cpm were diluted in 7 volumes of 1% Triton X-100 in phosphate-buffered saline. To each sample 4.4 μg of anti-β-galactosidase antibody (Promega, Madison, WI) was added, and the samples were incubated with rocking for 16 h at 4 °C. After continued incubation with 25 μl of PansorbinTM cells (Calbiochem) for 1 h, immunoprecipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed twice in phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.1% Triton X-100 and 1% SDS and twice in 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, containing 50 mm NaCl. The immunoprecipitates were resuspended in 50 μl of sample buffer (80 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 2% SDS, 100 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, and 0.02% bromphenol blue), boiled for 5 min, and loaded onto a 7.5% SDS-PAGE gel. The gel was fixed in 100% methanol for about 20 min and then treated for about 20 min with 20% 2,5-diphenyloxazole in glacial acetic acid. After soaking in water for 2 min, the gel was dried and exposed to x-ray film. The sequence-dependent AdoMetDC uORF encodes a hexapeptide with the amino acid sequence MAGDIS (8Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21886-21893Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). When the uORF was present in its natural context, 14 nucleotides from the 5′ cap, it suppressed translation of the associated cistron in T lymphocytes but not in nonlymphoid cell types (8Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21886-21893Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). When the uORF was placed in a position 47 nucleotides from the cap, it suppressed downstream translation irrespective of cell type (13Ruan H.J. Hill J.R. Fatemie-Nainie S. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17905-17910Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To test the influence of sequence on constitutive suppression of translation in the absence of cell-type regulation, the uORF of the AdoMetDC gene was placed 47 nucleotides from the cap using the hGH gene as a reporter (Fig. 1). Constructs with wild type and modified uORFs were transiently transfected into HeLa cells. Rate of hGH production and mRNA levels were measured (8Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21886-21893Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The wild type uORF reduced translational efficiency to approximately 1% that of the construct in which the uORF had been destroyed by modifying the initiator AUG codon to GUG. Consistent with previous results obtained with the AdoMetDC uORF located 14 nucleotides from the cap (9Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 726-731Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), alterations in codons 4, 5, and 6 all relieved a major proportion of the suppression, leaving a residual 14–40% inhibition compared with the 99% inhibition produced by the wild type uORF. This residual inhibition probably reflects the efficiency of translational reinitiation on an mRNA after termination in HeLa cells. To examine the coding requirements of a sequence-dependent uORF, it would be convenient to employ a microbial system to initially screen constructs generated by saturation mutagenesis of critical codons. To test whether the mammalian AdoMetDC uORF showed similar sequence-dependent activity in yeast, wild type and modified uORFs were placed into a derivative of the 5′ leader of theGCN4 mRNA in which all of the natural uORFs had been removed (14Miller P.F. Hinnebusch A.G. Genes Dev. 1989; 3: 1217-1225Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). The translational efficiencies of the mRNAs, based on β-galactosidase expression from these constructs, are given in TableII. A pattern similar, but not identical, to that seen in mammalian cells was observed. The wild type uORF encoding the peptide MAGDIS suppressed translation to a level 5% that of the construct in which the initiator AUG (codon 1) had been altered. This result, based on β-galactosidase activity, was qualitatively confirmed by labeling cells with [35S]methionine and immunoprecipitating the labeled β-galactosidase (Fig. 2). Alteration of codons 2 and 3 produced no significant change in expression from the wild type uORF (Table II), consistent with results with mammalian cells (9Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 726-731Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), whereas changes in codons 4 and 5 relieved translational suppression by 4- to 6-fold. However, in contrast to what we observed in mammalian cells, changing the sixth codon from serine to alanine only minimally influenced suppression, increasing expression by only about 2-fold over wild type. This suggested that the requirements at the 3′-terminal codon might be less demanding than originally suspected (9Hill J.R. Morris D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 726-731Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), a conclusion that was confirmed in later experiments (described below). To investigate further the behavior of the mammalian uORF in yeast, sucrose gradient centrifugation was performed on extracts prepared from yeast strains containing selected β-galactosidase reporter constructs with wild type and modified AdoMetDC uORFs. As was shown in Table II, mutation of the initiator AUG codon of the uORF abolished translational suppression, and as expected, this mRNA was well loaded with ribosomes (Fig. 3). In yeast, as well as in mammalian cells, the presence of the wild type uORF caused the associated mRNA to be associated strongly with monosomes, disomes, and trisomes (Fig. 3). The mRNA from a construct with codon 5 changed from isoleucine to valine, which retained suppressive activity of the uORF (see Fig. 4), showed a polysome distribution similar to wild type (Fig. 3). In contrast, modification of codon 5 to leucine, which relieved translational suppression (see Fig. 4), produced an mRNA that was efficiently loaded with ribosomes (Fig. 3). Therefore, the polysome patterns of these uORF-containing constructs parallel their translational efficiencies in yeast and support the apparent parallel between the activities of theAdoMetDC uORF in yeast and in mammalian cells. To explore further the coding specificity of the mammalian uORF, we randomly mutagenized codons 4, 5, and 6 and tested the influence of these altered uORFs on expression of the attached β-galactosidase reporter gene in yeast cells (Fig. 4). The activities of these constructs were compared with those of control constructs in which the uORF initiation codon had been destroyed

CD28 serves as a costimulatory cell surface molecule in T cell activation. CD28 signaling may also play a role in balancing the inflammatory/humoral (Th1/Th2) responses during an immune reaction. CD28 costimulation has been shown to promote the production of Th2 cytokines including interleukin (IL)-4, a key cytokine essential for Th2 differentiation and for the pathogenesis of allergic inflammation. In this study, we show that IL-4 mRNA and activity of the IL-4 promoter can be activated by the CD28 signal alone and are further augmented by CD28 costimulation of α-CD3- or mitogen-activated Jurkat T cells. Two important IL-4 enhancer elements, positive regulatory element (PRE)-I and P1, are found to respond to CD28 stimulation-induced transactivation. In contrast to the Th1 IL-2 CD28RE, activity of the IL-4 PRE-I and P1 can be induced by the CD28 signal alone. In correlation with CD28-induced transcriptional activation, AP-1 (c-Jun, JunD) and NF-κB/Rel (c-Rel, RelA) family members are found to bind to the two regulatory elements PRE-I and P1 upon CD28 stimulation. The data provide the first mapping of the CD28-responsive site in a Th2 cytokine gene, the IL-4 gene. They also show that the CD28 signal can directly activate a gene (e.g. IL-4) at the transcriptional level. CD28 serves as a costimulatory cell surface molecule in T cell activation. The data provide the first mapping of the CD28-responsive site in a Th2 cytokine gene, the IL-4 gene. They also show that the CD28 signal can directly activate a gene (e.g. IL-4) at the transcriptional level. Activation of T cells during an immune response requires two distinct signals: one from the engagement of the T cell receptor (TCR)1 with specific major histocompatibility complex antigens presenting peptides on antigen-presenting cells and a second signal originating from other cell surface receptors/ligands that mediate costimulation (1Crabtree G.R. Clipstone N.A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 1045-1083Crossref PubMed Scopus (626) Google Scholar). Work over the last several years has demonstrated that the CD28 glycoprotein, expressed on the surface of 80% of human T cells and on virtually all murine T cells, is one of the major costimulatory molecules (2June C.H. Bluestone J.A. Nadler L.M. Thompson C.B. Immunol. Today. 1994; 15: 321-331Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (187) Google Scholar, 3Lenschow D.J. Walunas T.L. Bluestone J.A. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1996; 14: 233-258Crossref PubMed Scopus (2327) Google Scholar). Ligation of CD28 with anti-CD28 (α-CD28) monoclonal antibodies (mAb) or cells expressing CD28 ligands (B7–1 and B7–2) in combination with limited concentrations of anti-CD3 (α-CD3) or antigen promotes cell cycle progression and increases interleukin (IL)-2 production by regulating IL-2 mRNA at both the level of transcription and translation (for a review, see Ref. 4Bluestone J.A. Immunity. 1995; 2: 555-559Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (511) Google Scholar). Thus, CD28 can deliver biochemical signals that function in synergy with TCR-mediated signaling to initiate and maintain T cell responses. Recent findings indicate that CD28 ligation acts not only synergistically with TCR ligation to maximize T cell signaling but also promotes cell differentiation. Several studies both in mice (5Shahinian A. Pfeffer K. Lee K.P. Kundig T.M. Kishihara K. Wakeham A. Kawai K. Ohashi P.S. Thompson C.B. Mak T.W. Science. 1993; 261: 609-612Crossref PubMed Scopus (1158) Google Scholar, 6Seder R.A. Paul W.E. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1994; 12: 635-673Crossref PubMed Scopus (1515) Google Scholar, 7Seder R.A. Germain R.N. Linsley P.S. Paul W.E. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 299-304Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar, 8Corry D.B. Reiner S.L. Linsley P.S. Locksley R.M. J. Immunol. 1994; 153: 4142-4148PubMed Google Scholar) and humans (9King C.L. Stupi R.J. Craighead N. June C.H. Thyphronitis G. Eur. J. Immunol. 1995; 25: 587-595Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar, 10Webb L.M. Feldmann M. Blood. 1995; 86: 3479-3486Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Palmer E.M. van Seventer G.A. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 2654-2662PubMed Google Scholar) support a fundamental role for CD28 in the early differentiation of T helper (Th) subsets toward a Th2 phenotype. In the absence of CD28 signaling, naive T cells are biased toward a Th1 phenotype. Th2 cells, which produce IL-4, -5, -6, -10, and -13, regulate humoral immune responses and Th1 cells, which secrete IL-2, tumor necrosis factor-β, and interferon-γ, are involved in cell-mediated and delayed type hypersensitivity immune responses. Thus, CD28 signaling may regulate the balance of inflammatory/humoral (Th1/Th2) responses during an immune reaction. It has been shown that CD28 costimulation may directly promote the production of Th2 cytokines (12Rulifson I.C. Sperling A.I. Fields P.E. Fitch F.W. Bluestone J.A. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 658-665PubMed Google Scholar). Both in humans (9King C.L. Stupi R.J. Craighead N. June C.H. Thyphronitis G. Eur. J. Immunol. 1995; 25: 587-595Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar) and in mice (12Rulifson I.C. Sperling A.I. Fields P.E. Fitch F.W. Bluestone J.A. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 658-665PubMed Google Scholar), increased CD28 ligation resulted in increased production of IL-4 and IL-5. Purified naive human T cells stimulated with α-CD3 in the absence of CD28 costimulation produce only IL-2 and interferon-γ, whereas the addition of α-CD28 mAb induced IL-4 (9King C.L. Stupi R.J. Craighead N. June C.H. Thyphronitis G. Eur. J. Immunol. 1995; 25: 587-595Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). IL-4 is a pleiotropic cytokine with a wide rage of biological effects on many hemopoietic and nonhemopoietically derived cells and tissues (13Paul W.E. Blood. 1991; 77: 1859-1870Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). IL-4 is also a well known cytokine that plays a central role in the pathogenesis of allergic inflammation by promoting Ig class switching to IgE (13Paul W.E. Blood. 1991; 77: 1859-1870Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In recent years, IL-4 was also shown to be the major determining factor in the differentiation of naive T cells into the Th2 phenotype and facilitating the humoral immune response (6Seder R.A. Paul W.E. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1994; 12: 635-673Crossref PubMed Scopus (1515) Google Scholar, 14Le Gros G. Ben-Sasson S.Z. Seder R. Finkelman F.D. Paul W.E. J. Exp. Med. 1990; 172: 921-929Crossref PubMed Scopus (840) Google Scholar). In the absence of IL-4, Th cells develop mainly into the Th1 phenotype (15Parronchi P. de Carli M. Manetti R. Simonelli C. Sampognaro S. Piccinni M.P. Macchia D. Maggi E. del Prete G. Romagnani S. J. Immunol. 1992; 149: 2977-2985PubMed Google Scholar,16Maggi E. Parronchi P. Manetti R. Simonelli C. Piccinni M.P. Rugiu F.S. De Carli M. Ricci M. Romagnani S. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 2142-2147PubMed Google Scholar). Up-regulation of the IL-4 production by CD28 signaling may be one of the mechanisms that promotes Th2 differentiation. The effect of CD28 on transcriptional activity of the Th1 IL-2 gene has been intensively studied. A NF-κB-like sequence between −164 and −154 and an adjacent AP-1 site of the IL-2 promoter was found to respond to the CD28 signal (17Fraser J.D. Irving B.A. Crabtree G.R. Weiss A. Science. 1991; 251: 313-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar, 18Verweij C.L. Geerts M. Aarden L.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 14179-14182Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Curtiss V.E. Smilde R. McGuire K.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 3567-3575Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 20McGuire K.L. Iacobelli M. J. Immunol. 1997; 159: 1319-1327PubMed Google Scholar). NF-κB/Rel and AP-1 transcription factors were found to participate in the formation of the CD28-responsive element-specific complex and to be involved in CD28-stimulated transactivation (20McGuire K.L. Iacobelli M. J. Immunol. 1997; 159: 1319-1327PubMed Google Scholar, 21Ghosh P. Tan T. Rice N.R. Sica A. Young H.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 1696-1700Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar, 22Bryan R.G. Li Y. Lai J.H. Van M. Rice N.R. Rich R.R. Tan T.H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 7933-7942Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 23Lai J.H. Horvath G. Subleski L. Bruder J. Ghosh P. Tan T.H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4260-4271Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar). In addition, several IL-2 NF-AT sites were found to respond to CD28 costimulation. CD28 inducibility was shown to be conferred by the AP-1 component in NF-AT/AP-1 composite elements (24Rooney J.W. Sun Y-L. Glimcher L.H. Hoey T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 6299-6310Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar). Although the CD28-responsive element of the IL-2 gene has been well studied, the CD28 response element of the IL-4 gene has not been characterized. Like the IL-2 gene, the IL-4 gene is regulated by multiple regulatory elements (for a review see Ref. 25Li-Weber M. Laur O. Davydov I.V. Hu C. Salgame P. Krammer P.H. Immunobiology. 1997; 198: 170-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). In this study, we provide the first report of CD28-responsive elements (CD28REs) in the IL-4 promoter. We show that two IL-4 promoter elements, PRE-I and P1, are responsive to the CD28 stimulation signal. In contrast to the IL-2 CD28RE, transcriptional activity of the IL-4 CD28REs can be activated by the CD28 signal alone. Upon CD28 stimulation, AP-1 (c-Jun, JunD) and NF-κB (c-Rel, p65/RelA) family proteins bind to these two elements and are involved in governing the CD28 responsiveness of the two elements. PRE-I and P1 belong to the most important regulatory elements of the IL-4 gene (26Abe E., R. Malefyt D.W. Matsuda I. Arai K. Arai N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 2864-2868Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar, 27Li-Weber M. Krafft H. Krammer P.H. J. Immunol. 1993; 151: 1371-1382PubMed Google Scholar, 28Chuvpilo S. Schomberg C. Gerwig R. Heinfling A. Reeves Grummt R.F. Serfling E. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 5694-5704Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar). Both sites are also shown to be involved in Th2-specific protein/DNA interactions and to be the potential regulatory elements for Th2-specific expression of the IL-4 gene (29Li-Weber M. Salgame P. Hu C. Davydov I.V. Krammer P.H. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 1194-1200PubMed Google Scholar, 30Wenner C.A. Szabo S.J. Murphy K.M. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 765-773PubMed Google Scholar). The finding of PRE-I and P1 as CD28REs may lead to a better understanding of CD28-mediated activation of the IL-4 gene. The cells used in this study were the human T-lymphoblastoid cell line Jurkat (J16-77). Cells were cultured in RPMI 1640 medium (Life Technologies, Inc.) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, 50 μg/ml gentamicin (Life Technologies), 6 mmHEPES (Life Technologies; 1 m solution), and 2 mml-glutamine (Life Technologies; 200 mm solution). Total cellular RNA was isolated using the RNeasy kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) according to the manufacturer's instructions. 1 μg of RNA was reverse transcribed with oligo(dT). PCR amplification was then performed for 35 cycles with specific primers (Stratagene, Heidelberg, Germany) for the human IL-4 (456-base pair PCR product) and the human β-actin (661-base pair PCR product) protein, respectively. The PCR products were then subjected to agarose gel electrophoresis. The luciferase reporter plasmid pLuc-IL4 (−269/+11) was constructed as described previously (31Li-Weber M. Salgame P. Hu C. Davydov I.V. Laur O. Klevenz S. Krammer P.H. J. Immunol. 1998; 161: 1380-1389PubMed Google Scholar). Multimer constructs containing DNA sequence of 1–3 copies of P1 (AATCTGGTGTAACGAAAATTTCCAATGTA) and PRE-I (AGCAAATTATGGTGTAATTTCCTATGCTGAA) and four copies of NF-κB consensus binding site (TCAGAGGGGACTTTCCGAGAGGCG) were constructed by ligation of each DNA sequence into the multicloning site of pATAT-Luc vector (a kind gift from Dr. T. Wirth, Institut für Medizinische Strahlen und Zellforschung, Würzburg, Germany). All constructs were confirmed by sequencing analysis. The p65/RelA expression plasmid (pCMV-p65) was kindly supplied by Dr. K. Schulze-Osthoff, Medizinische Klinik, Universität Tübingen, Germany). The c-Rel expression plasmid (pRSV-cRel) was kindly supplied by Dr. R. M. Schmid (Medizinische Klinik und Poliklinik, Universität Ulm). Jurkat T cells were transiently transfected by electroporation. 4 × 106/ml cells in RPMI 1640 medium and 15 μg of reporter plasmids were electroporated using a Bio-Rad Gene Pulser (Bio-Rad GmbH, München, Germany) set at 960 microfarads, 240 V. The transfected cells were allowed to recovered overnight and divided into aliquots. Each aliquot was further treated with α-CD3 mAb (OKT3 coated at 10 μg/ml), α-CD28 mAb (5 μg/ml), or α-CD3 plus anti-CD28 mAb for 8 and 16 h. Luciferase activity was determined in 10 μl of cell extract using the luciferase assay substrate (Promega) with an Duolumat LB9507 luminometer (Berthold, Germany). Nuclear extracts from Jurkat T cells unstimulated and stimulated for 2 h with either α-CD3 mAb (OKT3 coated at 10 μg/ml) or α-CD3 plus α-CD28 mAb (5 μg/ml) were prepared as described previously (29Li-Weber M. Salgame P. Hu C. Davydov I.V. Krammer P.H. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 1194-1200PubMed Google Scholar). EMSA was performed as published previously (29Li-Weber M. Salgame P. Hu C. Davydov I.V. Krammer P.H. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 1194-1200PubMed Google Scholar). Antibody analyses were done by preincubating the nuclear extracts with 1–2 μl of indicated antibodies for 20 min before adding the end-labeled probe. The synthetic oligonucleotides used for EMSA and competition experiments were as follows.
